PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Monticello. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1982 Code, as supplemented through May 7, 1991, and the 1957 Code, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1957 and 1982 Codes, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER AND RELATED LAWS CHT:1 CHARTER AND RELATED LAWS COMPARATIVE TABLES CHTCT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CHARTER INDEX CHTi:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Indexes 
    The indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of James S. Vaught, Senior Supervising Editor, and Connie Timmons, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Bruce A. Leinback, City Attorney, Emily Anderson, City Clerk/Treasurer, and Patti Claiborne, Deputy City Clerk, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

ORDINANCE NO. 2005-14 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE CITY OF MONTICELLO, FLORIDA; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances, City of Monticello, Florida," published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 90, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before June 7, 2005, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00, imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days, or any combination thereof. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the City may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the City Council to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. Ordinances adopted after June 7, 2005 that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7. This ordinance shall become effective upon passage. 
Passed and adopted by the City Council this 1st day of November, 2005. 
/s/ Julie S. Conley

PART I - CHARTER AND RELATED LAWS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The Charter herein compiled consists of Chapter 9026, Laws of Florida, 1921, and all subsequent acts relating to the City of Monticello, as amended. Where a section or an act has been amended, superseded or repealed by a later act, the amended, superseded or repealed section or act has been omitted. The origin of each amended section is given in parentheses following the section. 
The section numbers herein are the official numbers from section 1 through 47, with the exception of § 1.1. See note following said section. Beginning with section 48 the sections have been renumbered to conform to numerical sequence. 
The catchlines for the sections have been supplied by the editors to facilitate use of the compilation. Obvious misspellings have been corrected without notation, and a uniform format has been employed for citations to state law. Any other changes to the text are enclosed in brackets. Per the city's instructions, the provisions of the Charter have been degenderized by adding "[she]," "[her]" and "[herself]" as appropriate, and by adding "[councilmembers]" after the word "councilmen." 

Sec. 1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 1 of the Charter, which abolished the former municipal government of the city, has been deleted. 
Sec. 1.1. - Town designated city. 
    The name of the Town of Monticello located in Jefferson County is hereby changed to the City of Monticello, and wherever the word "Town" appears in Chapter 9026, Laws of 1921 [Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921)], as amended, where applicable the word "City" shall be substituted in lieu thereof. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1592, § 1) 
Editor's note- Section "1.1" amended Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921) generally, and not by specific section; therefore it is included herein as § 1.1 at the editor's discretion. Such section became effective upon approval of the voters on December 1, 1959. 
Sec. 2. - Boundaries of municipality established. 
    That the territorial boundaries constituting the municipality known as the City of Monticello, in the County of Jefferson, State of Florida, shall be as follows, to-wit: 
    Beginning at a point One Thousand Three Hundred and Seventy yards due North of the Court House, of Jefferson County, Florida, and running thence East One Thousand Three Hundred and Seventy yards, thence running due South Two Thousand Seven Hundred and Forty yards, thence running due West Two Thousand Seven Hundred and Forty yards, and thence running due North Two Thousand Seven Hundred and Forty Yards, and thence running One Thousand Three Hundred and Seventy yards due East to the starting point. 
Editor's note- The boundaries of the city have been changed by the following ordinances: 
Ord. of Ordinance No. Adoption Date  3- 4-1973 89-03.5  5- 2-1989  1-14-1974 89-04  6- 6-1989  2-13-1978 89-08 11- 7-1989  9- 5-1978 89-10 12- 5-1989  2-28-1978 90-04  3- 6-1990  3- 5-1985 90-08  5- 1-1990 90-09  9- 4-1990 91-08  1- 7-1992 92-05  9- 1-1992 2000-02  3- 7-2000 2000-09 11- 7-2000 2001-01  4- 3-2001 2001-01A 11- 6-2001 2005-01  1- 4-2005 2005-03  5- 3-2005  
Sec. 3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 3, "Obligations assumed by new municipality," which derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 4. - Rights, interest, etc., vested in new municipality. 
    That the title, right and ownership of property, uncollected taxes, dues, claims, judgments, decrees and choses in action held or owned by the said municipality of the City of Monticello shall pass and be vested in the municipal corporation hereby organized to succeed such municipality. 
Sec. 5. - Perpetual succession; right to sue; seal. 
    That said corporation shall have perpetual succession, shall sue and be sued, plead and be impleaded, and shall have a common seal which may be changed by the City Council at pleasure. 
Sec. 6. - Corporate powers. 
    That said Corporation may ... own[,] purchase, lease, receive, acquire and hold property, real and personal, beyond the limits of said corporation to be used for any and all such public purposes as the Mayor and City Council may deem necessary or proper; and may sell, lease or otherwise dispose of such property for the benefit of the City to the same extent as a natural person may; and the City Council may prescribe by ordinance the manner of making such conveyance. 
Editor's note- A portion of this section was either repealed or converted into an ordinance by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) which has not been readopted. 
Sec. 7. - Corporate officers. 
    That the government and corporate authority of said City shall be vested in the City Council to consist of five Councilmen, a Clerk-Treasurer, a Chief of Police and such other officers as may be appointed or elected in pursuance of law and the ordinances of said City. No person shall be eligible to hold an office herein provided for, except he/she be a resident and qualified elector of the City at the time of qualifying for said office and throughout the duration of his/her term. 
(Amended Res. No. 04-95, 8-1-1995) 
Sec. 8. - Mayor-Duties, powers. 
    That the Mayor shall be elected annually at the first meeting following the general election from among the current, elected City Councilmen [Councilmembers] to serve for one year, subject to removal or dismissal as a member of said Council, and shall hold his [her] office until his [her] successor is elected and qualified. He [she] shall attend all regular meetings of the council: Further, no additional salary shall be payable to the Mayor so elected. He [she] shall have power to preserve peace and order. The Mayor shall see that the ordinances are faithfully executed and the orders of the Council duly observed and enforced and exercise all the powers incident and usual to the due enforcement of his [her] jurisdiction. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1592, § 3; Ord. of 10-3-1972, § 2; Ref. of 1-12-1981) 
Sec. 9. - Same-Power of suspension. 
    That the Mayor shall have power to suspend any officer, except Councilmen [Councilmembers], for misconduct in office or neglect of duty, reporting his [her] action in writing with the reasons therefor to the next regular meeting of the Council for its approval or disapproval. 
Sec. 10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of § 10, pertaining to access to books and records and other powers of the mayor, which derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), have assumed ordinance status by virtue of the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) and their inclusion in the Monticello Code of Ordinances. Such provisions are included in the Code of Ordinances as § 2-1. 
Sec. 11. - Same-Approval of ordinance; failure to approve. 
    That every ordinance passed by the Council, before becoming a law, shall be presented to the Mayor under the certificate and seal of the Clerk. If the Mayor approves the same, he [she] shall sign it and return it to the Clerk, but if not, he [she] shall return it to the Clerk with his [her] objections in writing at or before the next regular meeting of the Council for reconsideration, and if the Council shall pass the ordinance by a two-thirds vote of all members present, it shall go into effect. If the Mayor shall fail to return any ordinance or shall return the same unsigned without objections in writing at or before the next regular meeting of the Council after its passage, he [she] shall be deemed to have approved the same and it shall become a law without his [her] signature. All ordinances receiving the approval of the Mayor, or becoming a law without his [her] approval, shall go into effect within five days after its first publication. 
Sec. 12. - Same-Communication with council; special meeting. 
    That the Mayor shall communicate from time to time to the Council such information and recommend such measures touching the public service as he [she] may deem proper and shall perform such duties as the ordinances may prescribe. He [she] may call special meetings of the Council and when called he [she] shall state the objects for which called, and the business of such meetings shall be confined to the subject so stated. 
Sec. 13. - Same-Appointment of special police officers. 
    When in his [her] opinion the public good requires it, the Mayor may appoint and discharge special policemen and detectives. 
Sec. 14. - Same-Impeachment. 
    That the mayor may be impeached by the Council for misfeasance, malfeasance or nonfeasance in office, for drunkenness, habitual intoxication or gross immorality. In the event that charges be preferred against the Mayor, the Council shall furnish him with a copy of the articles of impeachment and shall proceed without unnecessary delay to investigate and decide them. It shall require a two-thirds vote of the entire Council to remove him from office. 
Sec. 15. - Filling vacancies of corporate offices other than mayor or council. 
    That should there occur a vacancy in any of the offices of said municipality, except Mayor or Council, it shall be the duty of the Council to fill said vacancy as soon as possible by appointing a qualified elector of said municipality who shall hold the office for the unexpired term. 
Sec. 16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Pursuant to the referendum of January 13, 1986, adding a new § 26 to the Charter, former § 16 has been deleted pursuant to the request of the city. Former § 16 pertained to special elections to fill vacated council seats and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), as amended by a referendum of January 12, 1981. 
Sec. 17. - Town council-Composition, election, quorum, censure of fellow members, president of council. 
    The City Council shall be composed of five (5) members who shall be elected by the qualified electors for four years. Three Councilmen [Councilmembers] shall be elected hereunder at the general election to be held in 1922, and every four years thereafter, and four Councilmen [Councilmembers] shall be elected hereunder at the general election to be held in 1923 and every four years thereafter. The City Council shall be judges of the elections, returns, and qualifications of its own members and of the Mayor and other elective officers. A majority of the Councilmen [Councilmembers] shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business, but a smaller number may adjourn from time to time; and under the provisions of ordinances or rules of procedure may compel the attendance of absent members, and may prescribe penalties for the non-attendance or disorderly conduct of its members, and enforce the same, and may expel a member for improper conduct in office, drunkenness or gross immorality, by a two-thirds vote of the entire membership. The Council shall hold meetings at stated times, not less than one regular meeting each month, and may also hold special, called or adjourned meetings whenever occasions may require. The Council shall have the power and is hereby authorized to create such other and additional offices, and to provide for filling the same by election or appointment, as in its judgment may be necessary for the good government of such municipality; and shall have the power to abolish any such office so created whenever it may seem best for public interest to do so. The Council shall immediately after organization proceed to elect one of its members President, who shall preside over the Council, and who shall, in the case of the absence, disability, or death of the Mayor, act as Mayor for the time being. The President of the Council may call special meetings at any time on the request of three (3) members of the Council. 
(Ref. of 1-13-1986, § 1; Res. No. 91-01, § 1, 2-5-1991) 
Sec. 18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of § 18, which pertained to power of the city council to tax and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), were either repealed by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) or converted into an ordinance by such act which has not been readopted. The provisions of § 18 are adequately covered by such act. Property appraisals and tax collections are now provided by the county. See F.S. § 193.116. For municipal taxation generally, see F.S. § 166.201 et seq. 
Sec. 19. - Same-Police powers. 
    That the City Council shall have power to pass all necessary ordinances to ... make regulations to prevent the introduction of contagious or infections diseases into the City, and to make quarantine laws for that purpose and enforce the same within five miles of the City ... to provide for the enclosing, improving and regulating of the public grounds or parks belonging to the City ..., out of the corporate limits; ... 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 10915(1925), § 1) 
Editor's note- In general, limitations of municipal powers, such as those formerly provided in the above section, are no longer in effect. However, some of these provisions are still in force. One example is the subject of areas outside the city boundaries. See F.S. § 166.021. Under article III, section 11 of the Constitution of Florida, special laws may not pertain to punishment for crime. 
Sec. 20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 20, which pertained to compensation of councilmembers and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted. The provisions of section 20 were either repealed by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) or converted into an ordinance by such act which has not been readopted. The provisions of section 20 are adequately covered by such act. 
Sec. 21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of § 21, which pertained to council committees and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), have assumed ordinance status by virtue of the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) and their inclusion in the Monticello Code of Ordinances, except that "president'" has been changed to "mayor." Such provisions are included in the Code of Ordinances as § 2-2. 
Sec. 22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- The provisions of § 22, which pertained to the council's authority as to sidewalks and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), have assumed ordinance status by virtue of the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) and their inclusion in the Monticello Code of Ordinances. Such provisions are included in the Code of Ordinances as § 74-1. 
Sec. 23. - City clerk-treasurer. 
    Sec. 23a. The City Clerk-Treasurer shall be elected by the qualified electors of the City of Monticello and shall hold office for the term of four years or until his/her successor is elected and qualified. He/She shall act as Clerk of the City Council and shall perform all the duties now imposed upon the Clerk by ordinance not inconsistent with the provisions of this act. The Clerk's compensation shall be fixed by the Council. 
Editor's note- Amended Res. No. 04-95, adopted August 1, 1995, added § 57 to the Charter, providing that the clerk-treasurer is to be appointed by the council for a term of one year. 
    Sec. 23b. In addition to the duties outlined in Sec. 23a, the City Clerk-Treasurer shall be responsible for maintaining funds, accounts, payroll records, making disbursements to creditors, employees and others, and otherwise discharging all financial obligations including maintaining books and records at City Hall for public inspection during regular business hours. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1592, §§ 4, 5; Ref. of 1-13-1986, § 1; Amended Res. No. 04-95, 8-1-1995) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 24. 
Sec. 24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Amended Res. No. 04-95, adopted August 1, 1995, combined former §§ 23 (City Clerk) and 24 (City Treasurer) as 23a and 23b. Former § 24 was derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1592, § 5; and Ref. of 1-13-1986, § 1. 
Sec. 25. - Chief of police. 
    There shall be elected by the qualified electors of the City of Monticello, at the general election for city officers herein provided for, a Chief of Police, who shall hold office for four years or until his/her successor is elected and qualified. Such person shall give such bond as the council may require and shall receive such compensation as may be fixed by said council. The Chief of Police shall attend all regular and special meetings of the Council. It shall be his/her duty to aid in the enforcement of order under the direction of the presiding officer; to execute the commands of the Council from time to time; to aid in the enforcement of order under the direction of the Council and to perform such duties as may be appropriated [appropriate] to his/her office under the provisions of the law or as the same may not be inconsistent with this act, or may be hereafter required of him/her by ordinance. The Chief of Police shall have control of the police department, subject to the commands of the council, and shall have all police powers as established by law and arrest powers for violations involving the laws of the State of Florida or the Ordinances of the City of Monticello, as are or may be established by general law in the State of Florida. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1592, § 6; Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1593, § 1; Ref. of 1-13-1986, § 1; Amended Res. No. 04-95, 8-1-1995) 
Sec. 26. - Procedure for replacement of councilmembers. 
    If, during the elected term or the appointed term of any member of the City Council, he or she should die, resign, be removed or otherwise become unable to fulfill his or her term for a period of forty-five continuous days, the Mayor shall, within thirty days of determination of such vacancy, submit the name or names of his [her] nominees for replacement of such council member. Within fifteen (15) days of receipt of such nomination, the City Council shall approve or disapprove such nominee by a vote of the majority of the existing council, exclusive of the vote of the Mayor. Upon approval said nominee shall be sworn in and shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term or until the next general election, whichever occurs first. However, should said nominee be rejected, additional nominees shall be made and presented at each successive regular meeting until approved. 
(Ref. of 1-13-1986, § 2) 
Editor's note- The chief of police is responsible for the duties prescribed for the city marshal. In 1972, the voters of Florida approved article V of the state constitution, which terminated municipal courts, municipal judges and the warrants and process issuing therefrom. Section 26 formerly pertained to taxation; see the editor's note following §§ 27-34. 
Secs. 27-34. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sections 27-34 and former section 26 of the Charter, relating to taxation, have been deleted. The subject of municipal tax collections is now governed primarily by general law. See F.S. § 166.201 et seq. and F.S. ch. 192 et seq. 
Sec. 35. - General election. 
    Sec. 35a. General election. A general election for municipal officers shall be held on the second Tuesday in November, or on such date in November as may be set by the State of Florida, Secretary of State, Division of Elections, as the general election date for Florida. The City Council may authorize the Jefferson County Supervisor of Elections to administer such election and shall pay a reasonable fee for those services. The officers elected shall be sworn in and take office at the first meeting of the council in January, following the election, and shall immediately thereafter assume the duties of office to which they have been elected. 
    Sec. 35b. [Primary election.] In the event more than two persons qualify for elective office, the Council shall schedule a primary election for the second Tuesday in September, or such other date to coincide with the primary election set by the State of Florida, Secretary of State. The two candidates receiving the highest number of votes shall then appear on the ballot in the general election in November; however, such second primary will not be necessary should any candidate receive 50% plus 1 vote at the first primary. 
(Amended Res. No. 04-95, 8-1-1995) 
Sec. 36. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 36, which pertained to financial interest by city officers and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted. This section was either repealed or converted into an ordinance by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) which has not been readopted. 
Sec. 37. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 37, which pertained to road duty ordinances and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted. This section was either repealed or converted into an ordinance by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) which has not been readopted. 
Sec. 38. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 38, which pertained to bonds and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted. This section was either repealed or converted into an ordinance by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) which has not been readopted, since F.S. § 166.141 provides that "this part shall be full authority for the issuance of bonds authorized herein." 
Sec. 39. - Form of Ballot for City Elections. 
    The elections shall be held as near as may be in accordance with the law governing elections for State offices. The same form of ballot shall be used as is now provided for by law for use for elections of State officers. 
Editor's note- The first through third sentences of this section were either repealed or converted into ordinances by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) which have not been readopted, since the first sentence is preempted by F.S. §§ 97.041 and 166.032, and the second and third sentences are preempted by F.S. §§ 101.031, 101.041, 101.21, 101.635 and 101.75. 
Sec. 40. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 40, which pertained to adoption of state law relative to collection of taxes and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted. This section was either repealed or converted into an ordinance by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) which has not been readopted, as the section appears to be obsolete in light of F.S. § 193.116. 
Sec. 41. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 41, which pertained to adoption of state law relative to cities and towns and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted. This section was either repealed or converted into an ordinance by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act (F.S. ch. 166) which has not been readopted, since it is superfluous. 
Sec. 42. - Officers' interim power until successor elected. 
    The present officers of the City of Monticello shall hold their respective offices and perform all the functions thereunder until their respective terms have expired and the successors are elected and qualified. 
Sec. 43. - Ordinances not in conflict; in effect. 
    All ordinances of said City of Monticello heretofore in force, when not in conflict with the provisions hereof, shall be and remain in full force and virtue until repealed by the Council. 
Sec. 44. - Conflicting laws repealed. 
    All laws and parts of laws in conflict herewith shall be and the same are hereby repealed. 
Sec. 45. - Effect of act, time. 
    This Act shall take effect upon its ratification by the affirmative vote of a majority of the votes cast at an election to be held within the limits of the said City of Monticello as hereinafter provided. 
Sec. 46. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 46, "Election for basic charter," which derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted as obsolete. 
Sec. 47. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 47, "Canvass of results, filing," which derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), has been deleted as obsolete. 
Secs. 48-51. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Per F.S. § 166.21(5), sections 48-51, which pertained to license taxes on wholesale delivery vehicles and derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 19986(1939), §§ 1-4, have been converted into an ordinance and have been transferred to the Monticello Code of Ordinances. Such provisions are included in the Code of Ordinances as ch. 78, art. IV. 
Secs. 52-53.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Sections 52 through 53.1, which pertained to delinquent taxes, have been deleted. F.S. ch. 173 and F.S. §§ 192.053 and 197.056 adequately cover the subject. Sections 52 and 53 were derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 18704(1937), §§ 1, 2, and section 53.1 was derived from Laws of Fla. ch. 65-1943, § 1. 
Sec. 54. - Method of alteration of boundaries-In general. 
    The boundaries of the City of Monticello, Florida, may be changed, altered, modified, enlarged, extended or contracted in the manner now, or which shall hereafter be, provided by the general law of the State of Florida for such purposes. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1594, § 1) 
Editor's note- Sections 54-56 became effective when ratified by the voters on January 11, 1960. The controlling general law on municipal annexation or contraction is found in F.S. ch. 171. The provisions of sections 54-56 are therefore subject to such statute and will be subject to subsequent legislation adopted by the legislature of the state. The provisions of any special act or municipal charter relating to the adjusting of municipal boundaries in effect on October 1, 1974 are repealed except as otherwise provided in F.S. § 171.022. 
Sec. 55. - Same-Procedure. 
    The boundaries of the City of Monticello, Florida, in addition to, and as an alternative to, the manner provided by section 1 [54] hereof and in addition to, and as an alternative to, any other lawful manner in which said boundaries may now, or may hereafter, be changed, altered, modified, enlarged, extended or contracted, may, in the discretion of the City Council of said City, be enlarged or extended by either of the following procedures and in either of the following manners to-wit: 
(a)  The City Council of the City of Monticello, Florida, may, upon written petition of one or more individual person or persons owning land lying contiguous to said City, by ordinance duly passed as provided by law, declare its intention to annex to said City any unincorporated tract of land owned by such individual or individuals lying contiguous thereto and within Jefferson County, Florida, after the expiration of thirty (30) days from the date such ordinance becomes effective, which ordinance shall be published once a week for four (4) consecutive weeks (four publications being sufficient) prior to the expiration of thirty (30) days from the date such ordinance becomes effective in some newspaper published in the City of Monticello, Florida. In the event no newspaper is being published in said City at least once each week then at least three (3) typewritten or printed copies of said ordinance shall be posted for four (4) consecutive weeks prior to the expiration of thirty (30) days from the date such ordinance becomes effective in some conspicuous places in said city and three (3) typewritten or printed copies posted in like manner on the tract of land to be annexed. If at any time before the expiration of said thirty (30) days from the date such ordinance becomes effective, any ten (10) or more registered voters of the City or any one or more owners of real estate in the tract of land proposed to be annexed, shall object to such annexation, they may apply by petition to the Circuit Court of Jefferson County, Florida, setting forth in said petition the proposed proceedings of said City and the grounds of their objections thereto; whereupon the said Circuit Court shall designate a day for the hearing of said petition and shall order a copy of said petition, together with a notice of the hearing on same on the date designated, to be served upon the mayor of said City or in his [her] absence upon one (1) other member of the City Council of said City and all further action in the premises by said City shall be stayed until the further order of said court. If, upon the hearing of the said petition, the court shall find that valid legal reasons exist which would make it unlawful for said tract to be annexed and shall sustain the said objection, the said tract of land shall not be annexed; otherwise the petition shall be dismissed and the City Council may proceed at any time within one (1) year after the date of said order of dismissal to enact or adopt an ordinance annexing the said tract of land to said City and redefining the boundary lines of said City so as to include therein said tract of land. From and after the effective date of said ordinance of annexation said tract of land shall be legally and lawfully annexed to and shall be a part of said City. Such petition may be heard and determined by said court either in term time or in vacation, and questions of fact shall be determined by such court without a jury. If no petition is filed as aforesaid within the said thirty (30) days, the City Council may proceed at any time within one (1) year thereafter to enact or adopt an ordinance annexing the said tract of land to said City and redefining the boundary line of said City so as to include therein the said tract of land. From and after the effective date of said ordinance of annexation said tract of land shall be legally and lawfully annexed to and shall be a part of said City. Provided, however, that any unincorporated tract of land proposed to be so annexed shall, when annexed, constitute a reasonably compact addition to said City. The term "One individual person" as used hereinabove shall include a man and wife who own property jointly, in common, or in an estate by the entirety. 
(b)  The City Council of the City of Monticello, Florida, may, by ordinance duly passed as provided by law, declare its intention to annex to said City any unincorporated tract of land lying contiguous thereto and within Jefferson County, Florida. The question of whether or not the registered voters of said City and the registered voters of Jefferson County, Florida, who reside on said tract of land are in favor of said tract of land being annexed to said City may be submitted to a separate vote of the registered voters of said City, and of the registered voters of Jefferson County, Florida, who reside on said tract of land. Such election shall be called and conducted in the manner as is now or shall hereafter be provided by ordinance of said City, and the expense thereof paid by the City. The polling place or places for such election shall be the same as those prescribed as the polling place or places for regular municipal elections in said City. Full authority is hereby granted to the City Council of said City, in addition to any other lawful authority that may be vested in it, to enact or adopt such ordinances as it, in its discretion, shall determine to be reasonably necessary or desirable to carry out the full intent hereof. Such election, in the discretion of the City Council, may be held at the same time as any regular or other special city election is held. In the event a majority of the registered voters of Jefferson County, Florida, who reside on said tract of land actually voting at such election and a majority of the registered voters of said City actually voting at such election shall vote in favor of such annexation then, at any time within one (1) year after date of said election, the City Council may proceed to enact an ordinance annexing the said tract of land to said City and redefining the boundary lines of said City so as to include therein said tract of land. From and after the effective date of said ordinance of annexation said tract of land shall be legally and lawfully annexed to and shall be a part of said city. In the event the City Council shall follow the procedure set forth in this subsection then said tract of land shall not, within one (1) year after the date of said election, be annexed by this or any other method unless such annexation is approved by a majority of the registered voters of said City actually voting in such election and a majority of the registered voters of Jefferson County, Florida, who reside on said tract of land actually voting in such election. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1594, § 2) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 54. 
Sec. 56. - Liability of inhabitants of annexed lands for prior debts and obligations of city. 
    In the event the City Council follows either of the procedures set forth in section 2 [section 55] hereof, then all of the real estate and other property which may be within the tract of land so annexed, and the inhabitants thereof, at the time such annexation becomes effective, shall be liable, in the same manner and to the same extent as the inhabitants of, and the real and personal property within, the City as it existed immediately prior to and at the time of such annexation, for all debts and obligations, including bond indebtedness, of said city and subject to every species of taxation imposed upon the real estate and other property within the City of Monticello as it existed immediately prior to and at the time of such annexation. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 59-1594, § 3) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 54.

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Boundaries of city, § 2. 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Monticello, Florida" and may be so cited. Such code may also be cited as the "Monticello Code." 
(Code 1982, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    City. The term "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Monticello" followed it and shall extend to and include its several officers, agents and employees. 
    City council, council. The term "city council" or "council" means the city council of the City of Monticello. 
    Code. The term "Code" or "this Code" or "the Code" means the Code of Ordinances, City of Monticello, Florida, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day of the notice or act from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so computed shall be included unless it is a Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday, in which event the period shall run until the end of the next day which is neither a Saturday, a Sunday, nor a legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
    County. The term "the county" or "this county" means the County of Jefferson in the State of Florida. 
    Florida Statutes or F.S. The term "Florida Statutes" or "F.S." refers to the official statutes of the State of Florida as adopted by the state legislature, and amended from time to time. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Interpretation. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provisions imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper, proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and copartnerships, whether acting by themselves or a servant, agent or employee. 
    Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officers, employees, departments, boards, commissions or agencies. Whenever reference is made to officers, employees, departments, boards, commissions and agencies by title only, i.e., "city clerk," "the treasurer," etc., it shall be deemed to refer to the officers, employees, departments, boards, commissions and agencies of the City of Monticello. 
    Official time standard. Whenever certain hours are named, they shall mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use in this city. 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property. 
    Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall; may. The term "shall" is mandatory; the term "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    State. The term "the state" or "this state" means the State of Florida. 
    Street. The term "street" embraces streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city, to the boundaries of the rights-of-way. 
    Subordinates. Reference to an officer or agent of the city includes all duly authorized deputies, assistants and other subordinate officers and employees under the supervision of such officer. 
    Tenant, occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease of or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the present or past tense include the future as well as the present or past. 
    Year. The term "year," unqualified, means a calendar year. 
(Code 1957, §§ 1-2, 18-1; Code 1982, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- Definitions, F.S. § 1.01. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections and other headings. 
    The catchlines of the several subsections and sections and the headings of chapters, articles and divisions of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the subsection, section, chapter, article or division, and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles or substantive portions of such subsections, sections, chapters, articles or divisions, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such subsections, sections, chapters, articles or divisions, including the catchlines or other headings, are amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1957, § 1-3; Code 1982, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  In this section, "violation of this Code" means any of the following: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(b)  In this section, "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty unless it is specifically provided that the failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. 
(c)  Except as provided by law or ordinance, a person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00, imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days, or any combination thereof. If a violation of this Code is also a violation of state law, the violation shall be punished in the same manner and within the same limits as are prescribed for such violation of state law. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, with respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day that the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(e)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent suspension or revocation of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. 
(f)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent injunctive relief. 
(Code 1982, § 1-4) 
State Law reference- Confinement for failure to pay fine, F.S. § 56.011; fines, forfeitures and costs generally, F.S. § 34.191; time allowed to pay fine before being worked, § 34.161. 
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Monticello, Florida, is hereby amended to read as follows: ...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event that a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Monticello, Florida, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered ____________ , which said section reads as follows: ...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1957, § 1-6; Code 1982, § 1-5) 
Charter reference- Approval of ordinances, § 11. 
Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meanings of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
(Code 1982, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - History notes, editor's notes and state law references. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the editor's notes and state law reference notes throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall not be considered as part of the text of the Code. 
Sec. 1-8. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1957, § 1-4; Code 1982, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-9. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1957, § 1-5; Code 1982, § 1-8) 
Sec. 1-10. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1982, § 1-9) 
Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code; 
(2)  Any ordinance of the city promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or to the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(3)  Any ordinance fixing positions, classifications and salaries or otherwise affecting city officers or employees; 
(4)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinance of the city to any person, or any modification thereof; 
(5)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(6)  Any annual appropriation ordinance; 
(7)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes or fees, consistent with this Code; 
(8)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; 
(9)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(10)  Any administrative ordinances not inconsistent therewith; 
(11)  Any provision of the Charter or any special act made an ordinance by the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act; 
(12)  Any ordinance amending an act of the state legislature; 
(13)  Any ordinance adopting a comprehensive plan; 
(14)  Any ordinance rezoning a parcel of land; 
(15)  Any ordinance passed after June 7, 2005; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. 
(Code 1982, § 1-10) 
Sec. 1-12. - Assessment of court costs for criminal justice education. 
(a)  There is hereby assessed by the city, in compliance with F.S. § 938.15, an additional $2.00 as court costs, for criminal justice education, against every person convicted for violation of a state penal or criminal statute or convicted for violation of a city ordinance, where said offense occurred within the city. In addition, $2.00 shall be deducted from every bond estreature or forfeited bail bond related to such penal statutes or ordinances. However, no such assessment shall be made against any person convicted for violation of any state statute or county ordinance relating to the parking of vehicles. 
(b)  All such assessments shall be collected by the appropriate court and shall be remitted to the city and earmarked for criminal justice education for members of the police department. The use and expenditure of such funds shall be in accordance with state statutes. 
(Ord. of 1-8-1985, § 1; Code 1982, § 1-11) 
Sec. 1-13. - Enforcement of municipal ordinances. 
(a)  Code enforcement officers designated. The following employees/agents of the city are hereby designated as code enforcement officers: 
(1)  City superintendent. 
(2)  Animal control officers. 
(3)  Planning assistants/code enforcement. 
(b)  Qualifications of code enforcement officers. The training and qualifications of the code enforcement officers shall be determined by the city. 
(c)  Issuance of citations authorized. Code enforcement officers are authorized to issue citations to individuals when, based upon personal investigation, the officer has reasonable cause to believe that the individual has committed a civil infraction in violation of a duly enacted ordinance of the city, which is subject to enforcement under the provisions of this section. 
(d)  Notice to correct violation. Prior to issuing a citation, the code enforcement officer shall provide notice to the individual that the individual has committed a violation of a duly enacted ordinance and shall establish a reasonable time period within which the person must correct the violation. Such time period shall be 30 calendar days. If, upon personal investigation, the code enforcement officer finds that the individual has not corrected the violation within the 30-calendar-day time period, the code enforcement officer shall issue a citation to the person who has committed the violation. 
(e)  Immediate issuance of citation. A code enforcement officer may immediately issue a citation without providing a reasonable time period for correction, if a repeat violation is found, or if the code enforcement officer has reason to believe that the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety, and welfare, or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible. 
(f)  Form and contents of citation. The citation issued by a code enforcement officer shall be in the form prescribed by the city and shall contain: 
(1)  The date and time of issuance; 
(2)  The name and address of the person to whom the citation is issued; 
(3)  The date and time the civil infraction was committed; 
(4)  The facts constituting reasonable cause; 
(5)  The number or section of the Code or ordinance violated; 
(6)  The name and authority of the code enforcement officer; 
(7)  The procedure for the person to follow in order to pay the civil penalty or to contest the citation; 
(8)  The applicable civil penalty if the person elects to contest the citation; 
(9)  The applicable civil penalty if the person elects not to contest the citation; and 
(10)  A conspicuous statement that, if the person fails to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed or fails to appear in court to contest the citation, the person shall be deemed to have waived his/her right to contest the citation and that, in such case, judgment may be entered against the person for an amount up to the maximum civil penalty. 
(g)  Filing of copies of citation. After issuing a citation to an alleged violator, the code enforcement officer shall deposit the original citation and one copy of the citation with the county court. 
(h)  Maximum civil penalty. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, a violation of a city ordinance subject to enforcement under the provisions of this section shall constitute a civil infraction with a maximum civil penalty of $500.00. 
(i)  Penalty for first offense and repeat violation. If an individual has been issued a citation pursuant to the provisions of this section and does not contest the citation, the civil penalty for the first offense shall be $100.00. If the individual has been issued a citation for a repeat violation and chooses not to contest the citation, the civil penalty shall be $250.00. 
(j)  Payment of penalty. An individual who is issued a citation shall have seven calendar days within which to pay the applicable civil penalty for an uncontested citation, or to contest the citation in the county court. The civil penalties for the violation of municipal ordinances subject to the provisions of this section may be paid in cash or by money order, made payable to the city, and shall be paid at the office of the city clerk at the city hall. 
(k)  Right to contest citation. If the individual who has been issued the citation wishes to contest the citation, he/she must do so within seven calendar days following the date the citation was issued. 
(l)  Failure to pay penalty or contest citation. If the individual to whom a citation was issued fails to pay the civil penalty within seven calendar days of the date the citation was issued, and fails to contest the citation within the same seven-calendar-day time period, the individual shall be deemed to have waived his/her right to contest the citation, and judgment may be entered against him/her for an amount up to the maximum civil penalty of $500.00. 
(m)  Procedure for contesting citation. If an individual wishes to contest a citation, he/she must do so within seven calendar days by notice in a form to be prescribed by the city and available from the office of the city clerk. The original and one copy of the notice, together with a copy of the citation which he/she is contesting, must be deposited with the county court, and an additional copy delivered either before or immediately thereafter to the office of the city clerk. 
(n)  Refusal to accept citation. Any person who willfully refuses to sign and accept a citation issued by a code enforcement officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor in the second degree as provided in F.S. § 775.082 or § 775.083. 
(o)  Applicability. The provisions of this section shall apply to enforcement of the provisions of chapter 6, chapter 18, chapter 54, article IV of chapter 66, and chapter 74. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the enforcement of building codes adopted pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 553.73 as they apply to construction, provided that a building permit is either not required or has been issued by the city or the county. 
(Ord. No. 2000-04, 8-1-2000) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

Sec. 2-1. - Supervision of city officers by mayor; mayor's access to books and records. 
    The mayor shall have general supervision over all city officers and may examine into the condition of the offices, the books and records and papers thereof and therein, and the manner of conducting official business. He/she shall report to the council all violations or neglect of duty on the part of any official that may come to his/her knowledge. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), § 10) 
Sec. 2-2. - Council committees. 
    The council shall by ordinance or resolution determine the number of standing committees, and the number of members of which each of said committees shall consist, and shall designate the character and duties of each. The mayor shall appoint said committees annually as soon after organization as practicable. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), § 21) 
Sec. 2-3. - Use of local government infrastructure surtax funds. 
    In accordance with state law, the city may, through its elected officials, use local government infrastructure surtax funds for any public purpose. 
(Ord. No. 95-03, § 1, 4-4-1995) 
Secs. 2-4-2-30. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - PENSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Actuarial soundness of retirement systems, F.S. § 112.61 et seq. 

Sec. 2-51. - Pension plan established. 
    By this division, the city hereby exercises the rights provided under the Florida Statutes for establishment of retirement benefits for its employees. 
(Code 1957, § 15-18; Code 1982, § 18-16) 
Sec. 2-52. - Fire and police pensions. 
    The pension plan adopted in this division shall not include personnel of the fire and police departments, who are covered by other provisions. Said fire and police pensions are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1957, § 15-19; Code 1982, § 18-17) 
Sec. 2-53. - Eligibility; city contributions. 
(a)  The city pension plan shall be a defined contribution plan and shall be established to provide the following: 
(1)  All regular full time employees (other than police officers and firefighters) who have completed one year of service as a full time employee are eligible to participate in the plan. 
(2)  The city will contribute an amount equal to ten percent of the employee's annual compensation for each eligible employee. 
(3)  Employees will be fully vested in the plan after six years of eligible service. 
(4)  Provisions relating to the vesting schedule, normal retirement age, and other terms of the plan are outlined in the agreement which is attached as exhibit A to the ordinance from which this section is derived, which is incorporated herein by reference. 
(b)  The mayor is hereby authorized to execute, on behalf of the city, the agreement attached as exhibit A, and all other documents necessary to implement the defined contribution plan. 
(Code 1957, § 15-19; Code 1982, § 18-18; Ord. No. 98-06, 7-7-1998) 
State Law reference- Limitation of benefits, F.S. § 112.65. 
Sec. 2-54. - Additional benefits for police officers. 
(a)  Monthly retirement income. The amount of monthly retirement income payable to a police officer who retires on or after his/her normal retirement date shall be an amount equal to the number of his/her years of credited service multiplied by 23/4 percent of his/her average final compensation. 
(b)  Member contribution. The members of the retirement plan shall increase their employee contributions from five percent to seven percent to fund the increased retirement benefit, until such time that it is actuarially determined that their contributions may be reduced to the original five-percent contribution rate and still maintain the increased retirement benefit. 
(c)  Application. All other provisions of F.S. ch. 185 shall be fully applicable, except for the provisions of this section, to the city's municipal police officers' retirement trust fund. The increased pension benefits in the same percentage of increase as provided for by this section shall apply to all police officers now eligible for retirement benefits, but not now retired, and all future retirees under the provisions of the city's municipal police officers' retirement trust fund, F.S. ch. 185. 
(d)  Pretax contribution. Effective on the first date when administratively feasible subsequent to May 4, 2004, the contributions made by each member of the police officers' retirement plan to the city's municipal police officers' retirement trust fund shall be designated as employer contributions, pursuant to the provisions of section 414(h) of the Internal Revenue Code, 26 USC 414. Such designation is contingent upon the contributions being excluded from the members' gross income for federal income tax purposes. For all other purposes of the retirement plan, such contributions shall be considered to be member contributions. 
(Code 1982, § 18-19; Ord. No. 88-02, §§ 1-3, 3-1-1988; Ord. No. 2004-03, § 1, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 2-55. - Additional benefits for firefighters. 
(a)  Monthly retirement income. 
(1)  The minimum benefit provisions set forth in F.S. ch. 175, except as otherwise provided for in this section, are hereby adopted as the benefit provisions of the firefighters' retirement trust fund. 
(2)  For purposes of determining all benefits for members covered under the fund monthly benefits attributable to each year of creditable service shall be the greater of: (i) 2.75 percent of average final compensation, or (ii) $25.00, effective May 2, 2017. This benefit will be payable to all current retirees beginning May 2, 2017. 
(b)  Member contribution. The members of the retirement plan shall increase their employee contributions from five percent to seven percent to fund the increased retirement benefit, until such time that it is actuarially determined that their contributions may be reduced to the original five-percent contribution rate and still maintain the increased retirement benefit. 
(c)  Application. All other provisions of F.S. ch. 175 shall be fully applicable, except for the provisions of this section, to the city's municipal firefighters' pension trust fund. The increased pension benefits in the same percentage of increase as provided for by this section shall apply to all firefighters now eligible for retirement benefits, but not now retired, and all future retirees under the provisions of the city's municipal firefighters' pension trust fund, F.S. ch. 175. 
(d)  [Additional provisions.] In addition to the provisions of F.S. § 175.091, the following provisions are applicable regarding the contributions: 
(1)  State contribution. All future receipts of the chapter 175 money will be used by the city to offset its contributions to the pension plan. 
(2)  Unused accumulated 175 reserve; effective for the contribution for the fiscal year ended September 30, 2016. The unused accumulated reserve of $26,121.00 will be used to increase the multiplier from $21.00 to $25.00 per year of service. 
(e)  Defined contribution component. Pursuant to the requirements of F.S. § 175.351(6), a defined contribution plan component is established in addition to the defined benefit component of this local law plan. This defined contribution component is not currently funded. If the plan is funded, the board of trustees has the authority to adopt rules regarding the operation of the defined contribution component of the local law plan. 
(Code 1982, § 18-20; Ord. No. 88-03, §§ 1-3, 4-5-1988; Ord. No. 2000-03, 3-7-2000; Ord. No. 2017-01, § 1-3, 5-2-2017) 
Secs. 2-56-2-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SOCIAL SECURITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Social security for public employees, F.S. ch. 650. 

Sec. 2-81. - Benefits extended. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective as of April 1, 1956, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law, nor excepted in this division, the benefits of the system of old age and survivors' insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto and by F.S. ch. 650, and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment, as defined in F.S. § 650.02, performed in the employ of the city by employees and officials thereof, except service in the legislative class of elective positions. 
(Code 1957, § 15-1; Code 1982, § 18-31) 
Sec. 2-82. - Mayor directed to execute agreements. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the division of retirement of the state department of administration as state agency for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the system of old age and survivors' insurance to the employees and officials of this city as provided in sections 2-81 and 2-88, which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the city as are found by the state agency to be necessary and proper, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed on and after April 1, 1956. 
(Code 1957, § 15-3; Code 1982, § 18-32) 
State Law reference- Submission of plans by political subdivisions, F.S. § 650.05(1). 
Sec. 2-83. - Adoption of act. 
    The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges and other conditions thereunto appertaining of title II of the Social Security Act, as amended, for and on behalf of all officers and employees of its departments and agencies to be covered under the agreement. 
(Code 1957, § 15-7; Code 1982, § 18-33) 
Sec. 2-84. - Custody of funds; duties of city clerk. 
    The city clerk is hereby designated as the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the city, and the city clerk is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this division. 
(Code 1957, § 15-8) 
Sec. 2-85. - Records and reports. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations and shall adhere to the regulations of the state agency. 
(Code 1957, § 15-6; Code 1982, § 18-35) 
State Law reference- Reports by political subdivisions, F.S. § 650.05(1)(e); rules and regulations made by state agency, § 650.07. 
Sec. 2-86. - Appropriations from general fund. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from the general fund, such amounts at such times as may be required to pay promptly the contributions and assessments required of the city as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1957, § 15-5; Code 1982, § 18-36) 
State Law reference- Contributions by political subdivisions, F.S. § 650.05(3)(a). 
Sec. 2-87. - Authority to withhold wages. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 2-81 are hereby authorized to be made and shall be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1957, § 15-4; Code 1982, § 18-37) 
State Law reference- Contributions by employees, F.S. § 650.05(3)(b). 
Sec. 2-88. - Employees covered by existing retirement system. 
    There is hereby excluded from this division any authority to include in any agreement entered into under section 2-82 any service, position, employee or official now covered by or eligible to be covered by an existing retirement system. 
(Code 1957, § 15-2; Code 1982, § 18-38) 
Chapter 6 - ADVERTISING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Sign ordinances, F.S. §§ 166.0425, 479.155; removal of outdoor advertising, F.S. § 479.15; fraudulent practices, F.S. ch. 817. 

Sec. 6-1. - Placing banners or signs across streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to extend any banner or canvas sign across any public street, park or other way of the city without first having obtained permission from the city council. 
(Code 1957, § 2-8; Code 1982, § 3-3) 
Sec. 6-2. - Posting bills or other advertising matter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to post any bills or other advertising matter upon any permanent or temporary structure or building, pole or tree located in any street, park or other public way or place within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1957, § 2-7; Code 1982, § 3-6) 
State Law reference- Advertisement fastened to tree on right-of-way of road, F.S. § 479.11. 
Sec. 6-3. - Distribution of handbills. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill upon any premises, if requested by any person thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on said premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof, a sign bearing the words "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement" or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of said premises do not desire to be solicited or to have their right of privacy disturbed, or to have any such handbills left upon such premises. 
(b)  No person shall distribute, deposit, place, throw, scatter or cast any commercial or noncommercial handbill in or upon any private premises which are inhabited, except by handing or transmitting any such handbill directly to the owner, occupant or any other person then present in or upon such private premises; provided, however, that in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted as provided in this section, the aforesaid person, unless requested by anyone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any such handbill in or upon such inhabited private premises, if such handbill is so placed or deposited as to secure or prevent such handbill from being blown or drifted about such premises or elsewhere, except that mailboxes may not be so used when so prohibited by federal postal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1982, §§ 3-7, 3-8) 
Chapter 10 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, F.S. ch. 561 et seq. 

Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
    The city hereby adopts by reference the definitions set out in F.S. § 561.01. 
(Code 1957, § 3-1; Code 1982, § 4-1) 
Sec. 10-2. - Duty of arresting officer to preserve evidence.
