    Upon the arrest of any person charged with the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, it shall be the duty of the arresting officer to take into his/her custody all alcoholic or intoxicating liquors or beverages whether spirituous, vinous or malt, which may be found in the possession, custody and control of the person arrested, and to safely keep and preserve the same and have it forthcoming at any trial of such person for the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1957, § 3-15; Code 1982, § 4-6) 
Sec. 10-3. - Proof and testimony in prosecutions. 
(a)  In any prosecution under the provisions of this chapter it shall not be necessary for the city or any officer, in pleading or by evidence, to negate the existence in point of fact of any of the exceptions contained in this chapter, but the existence of any such exceptions in point of fact shall be defensive matter in any such prosecution. 
(b)  In any prosecution under the provisions of this chapter it shall not be necessary for the city or any officer to allege or prove the particular name, kind, character or contents of any alcoholic or other intoxicating liquors or beverages, whether spirituous, vinous or malt, or other liquors or liquids, but it shall be sufficient to allege generally and to prove that the same are alcoholic or intoxicating liquors or beverages, or other liquors or liquids, within the prohibitions of this chapter. 
(c)  In all prosecutions for the violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, proof that the liquor in question was and is known as whiskey, moonshine whiskey, shine, rum, gin or brandy or other similar name or names shall be prima facie evidence that said liquor is intoxicating and contains more than 3.2 percent of alcohol by weight. Any person who, by past experience in the handling or use of intoxicating liquors, or who by taste, smell or the drinking of any such liquors has knowledge as to the intoxicating nature thereof, may in any prosecution for violation of the provisions of this chapter testify as to his/her opinion as to whether such beverage or liquor is or is not intoxicating, and a conviction based upon such testimony shall be valid. 
(Code 1957, § 3-14; Code 1982, §§ 4-9-4-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 562.47(2). 
Sec. 10-4. - Sale near church or school. 
    No beer, wine or other intoxicating beverages shall be sold within 300 feet of an established church or school, which distance shall be measured by following the shortest route of ordinary pedestrian travel along the public thoroughfare from the main entrance of said place of business to the main entrance of the church and, in the case of schools, to the nearest point of the school grounds in use as part of the facilities. As used herein, the term "school" shall mean and refer to a nursery school or children's day care facility, or a public or private elementary, middle or high school. 
(Code 1957, § 3-7; Code 1982, § 4-12; Ord. No. 2003-06, § 1, 10-7-2003) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate the location of alcoholic beverage businesses, F.S. § 562.45. 
Sec. 10-5. - Hours and days of sale. 
    No alcoholic beverages may be sold, consumed, served or permitted to be served or consumed in any premises holding a license under the State Division of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m., Tuesday through Saturday, and from 12:00 a.m. on Sunday until 7:00 a.m. on Monday, except as provided herein. Alcoholic beverages in sealed containers may be sold in licensed premises, only for consumption off the premises where sold, on Sunday between the hours of 12:00 p.m. (noon) and 10:00 p.m. 
    Additionally, businesses holding a public food service license, a hotel license, or a bed and breakfast license issued by the Florida Department of Business and Professional Regulation that also have a license issued by the Division of Alcoholic Beverages and Tobacco to sell or serve alcoholic beverages on the same premises, may sell and serve alcoholic beverages on those premises between the hours of 12:00 p.m. (noon) and 10:00 p.m. on Sundays, provided that such entities derive at least 51 percent of their gross revenue from activities other than alcohol sales. Entities that are recognized as 501(c)(3) organizations by the Internal Revenue Service, and that also have a license to sell or serve alcoholic beverages, may sell and serve alcoholic beverages in conjunction with an artistic, educational, cultural, promotional, civic or charitable event occurring on the premises between the hours of 12:00 p.m. (noon) and 10:00 p.m. on Sundays, provided that such entities derive at least 51 percent of their gross revenue from activities other than alcohol sales. 
(Code 1957, § 3-8; Code 1982, §§ 4-14-4-16; Ord. of 5-6-1980; Ord. No. 87-02, 4-7-1987; Ord. No. 88-04, 3-1-1988; Ord. No. 2013-05, § 1, 8-6-2013; Ord. No. 2015-02, § 1, 2-3-2015) 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate hours of business, F.S. § 582.45. 
Sec. 10-6. - Open containers within 500 feet of licensed establishments. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for anyone to consume or possess open containers of beer, wine, alcoholic beverages or intoxicating liquors off of the premises of an establishment dealing in intoxicating beverages and within 500 feet of the premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages, except within closed buildings or on premises occupied solely by residential structures. The distance set forth herein shall be measured from the shortest route of ordinary pedestrian travel along public thoroughfares from the principal entrance of the establishment dealing in intoxicating beverages to the location of the violation of this section. 
(b)  Posting of signs. Each establishment dealing in intoxicating beverages shall at all times, when such establishment is open to the public or is dispensing or selling intoxicating beverages or alcoholic liquors, have located in the interior as well as the exterior portions of the building licensed for sale of such beverages, at a location at which it can be readily seen and read by customers of the establishment, a sign prominently displayed of a size at least one foot by two feet containing the following information: 
IT IS UNLAWFUL TO CONSUME OR POSSESS ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN AN OPEN CONTAINER WITHIN 500 FEET OF THIS ESTABLISHMENT AND OFF OF THESE LICENSED PREMISES-ORDINANCE NO. 86-11 
(c)  Location and form of signs; violations. The chief of police shall prescribe by rule the location for the signs and the size of the lettering, following as his/her guidelines the criteria set forth above. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any establishment dealing in intoxicating beverages to fail to comply with this section or for any person to sell, dispense or serve alcoholic or intoxicating beverages in any establishment which is not in compliance with this section. The requirements of this section shall then apply to all establishments dealing in intoxicating beverages whether or not then licensed or licensed in the future. 
(d)  Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to establishments holding a public food service license and a license issued by the Florida Division of Alcohol Beverages and Tobacco, which also possess valid temporary use permits issued by the City of Monticello for the use of city sidewalks in the downtown B-l business zoning district for restaurant tables and seating outside such establishments. Beer, wine or other alcoholic beverages may be consumed at such sidewalk cafes provided that the purchasers are seated at tables, and the alcoholic beverages are served at a time when food service is available at the sidewalk café. 
(Code 1982, § 4-19; Ord. No. 86-11, § 1, 8-5-1986; 2018-06, § 1, 4-3-2018) 
Chapter 14 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POOLROOMS AND BILLIARD PARLORS 

Sec. 14-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Obstruction. Any frosting or paint upon any window not situated in any building used under the provisions of this article, or that may hereafter be constructed in any such building, or any swinging doors (excepting doors used for the purpose of closing and fastening such place of business) or any partition or wall which may be constructed in any such building which shall have the effect of obstructing or obscuring a public view of the tables or of any part of the premises where billiards or pool is played, or where liquors, wines or beers are sold or dispensed, from any of the streets or alleys from which entrance to such building may be had, shall be deemed and held an obstruction within the meaning of this article. 
(Code 1957, § 3-13; Code 1982, § 20-1) 
Sec. 14-32. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any person or the agent or employee of such person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-4 of this Code, and in addition thereto the city license for conducting a place regulated herein shall forthwith and immediately stand revoked, cancelled and annulled. 
(Code 1957, § 13-27; Code 1982, § 20-2) 
Sec. 14-33. - Obstructing view of interior. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or tenant of any building situated within the corporate limits of the city and used by such owner, occupant or tenant as a place for playing billiards or pool, or as a place for the sale of spirituous liquors, wines or beers, to erect or maintain screens, frosted glass windows or other obstructions in or about such places of business, or suffer any such screens, frosted glass windows or other obstructions already erected to remain, which prohibit a public view of the interior of such place being had from any of the streets or alleys of the city from which entrance to such building may be had. 
(Code 1957, § 3-12; Code 1982, § 20-3) 
Sec. 14-34. - Business hours. 
    No poolroom or billiard parlor shall be open for the public and no game shall be allowed therein on Sunday or between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. Patrons must cease playing at 10:00 p.m. and must be off the premises by 10:30 p.m. 
(Code 1957, § 13-23; Code 1982, § 20-4) 
Sec. 14-35. - Gambling. 
    Any person who is the owner of or who is in charge of and conducting any poolroom or billiard parlor or other place where pool tables and billiard tables and equipment incidental thereto are kept and maintained for the use of the public and shall allow any gambling, betting or wagering to be carried on or conducted in and about the place shall be guilty of a second degree misdemeanor, as defined in F.S. § 775.01 et seq. 
(Code 1957, § 13-24; Code 1982, § 20-6) 
State Law reference- Holder of license to operate pool or billiard table permitting gambling, F.S. § 849.07. 
Sec. 14-36. - Permitting minors to participate in games or to loiter about premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person keeping or carrying on either himself/ herself or in connection with another or for another any poolroom or billiard parlor with the general public to allow a minor to engage in any game therein or to loiter in such place. 
(Code 1957, § 13-26; Code 1982, § 20-7) 
State Law reference- Proprietor of poolroom permitting minors to gamble, F.S. § 849.04. 
Chapter 18 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Animal industry, F.S. ch. 585; cruelty to animals, F.S. ch. 828; livestock, F.S. ch. 534; livestock at large, F.S. ch. 588. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Killing, wounding or molesting wild birds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to kill or wound, or attempt to kill, capture or molest, within the city limits, any mockingbird, redbird, thrush, woodpecker, dove or other wild bird. 
(Code 1957, § 4-6; Code 1982, § 5-3) 
Sec. 18-2. - Permit for keeping livestock. 
(a)  Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to have, keep, house, stall, stable, domicile or otherwise maintain upon his/her premises, or the premises occupied by him/her, within the corporate limits of the city, any live horse, mule, donkey, jackass, burro, pony, cow, hog, sheep or goat, except upon an unrevoked written permit so to do from the city clerk, as provided in this section. 
(b)  Issuance. The permit as required in this section shall be issued by the city clerk without charge upon proper application and upon the written agreement of the person receiving the permit to obey the rules and regulations of the council covering the privilege for which the permit is issued, which permit shall be subject to the approval of the council. The rules and regulations shall be written upon the permit, shall be construed to be a part thereof and shall be subscribed to and signed by the person making application therefor. 
(c)  Revocation. The permit as required in this section shall be revocable by the council for due cause, or upon the failure of the person receiving the permit to comply with any of the rules and regulations applicable thereto, and when so revoked the permit shall be null and void. After any permit has been revoked, the council may refuse to approve any subsequent permit to the same person until the applicant therefor fully complies with all the rules and regulations. The violation of any ordinance of the city governing the keeping of livestock shall also be considered cause for revocation by the council of any permit issued hereunder. 
(Code 1957, §§ 4-7-4-9; Code 1982, §§ 5-4-5-6) 
Sec. 18-3. - Nuisance animals. 
(a)  Generally. Any animal which habitually barks, whines, howls or causes other objectionable noise, which is at large, which chases or runs after persons or vehicles, which destroys or damages any property of another person, which causes serious annoyance to a neighboring resident and interferes with the reasonable use and enjoyment of his/her property, or which is otherwise offensive so as to create a nuisance shall be deemed to be committing an act in violation of this chapter. Any person who owns, keeps or harbors any animal which is deemed in violation of this section shall be guilty of a second degree misdemeanor. 
(b)  Complaints. Upon receipt of an "affidavit of complaint" signed by two or more residents of the city, each complainant residing in separate dwellings in the vicinity in which a violation of subsection (a) of this section occurred, made under oath before an individual authorized by law to take acknowledgments and setting forth the nature of and the date of the act, the owner of the animal, the address of the owner and a description of the animal doing such act, the impounding officer shall investigate the complaint to determine whether the act complained of violates this section. In the event that the act complained of constitutes a violation of this section, the impounding officer shall enforce this section pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Enforcement. The methods of enforcing this section shall be to: 
(1)  Issue a notice of violation to the owner of such animal; such notice of violation shall state the date and time of the issuance of the notice, the name and address of the person in violation, the date of the offense, the offense committed, a description of the animal involved and a demand that the offense be abated within 72 hours after the issuance of the notice. If the person shall fail to abate the offense, the impounding officer shall cause a warrant to be issued against the person in violation of this section. 
(2)  Impound such animal. 
(Code 1957, §§ 4-15-4-17; Code 1982, §§ 5-7-5-9) 
State Law reference- Abatement of nuisance by injunction, F.S. §§ 60.05, 60.06; public nuisances generally, F.S. ch. 823; nuisances injurious to health, F.S. ch. 386. 
Sec. 18-4. - Livestock or dangerous animals running at large; impoundment generally. 
(a)  Running at large prohibited; impoundment authorized. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any animal of the equine species, or any fowl, cow, calf, bull, boar, goat or dangerous or vicious animal of any species, to run in or on any of the public thoroughfares, squares or unenclosed lands, or other public lots of the city; and it shall be the duty of the police, on information or view, to cause the same to be impounded; nor shall such animal be restored to the owner until such owner shall pay as provided in this section for each and every such animal the cost of impounding, provided that before impounding any mischievous animal, whose owner may be known to the police, the police shall notify such owner to keep such animal confined, and if thereafter such animal is found upon the thoroughfares, squares, unenclosed land or lots aforesaid at large, the same shall be impounded without notice, as provided above. 
(b)  Duties of chief of police. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to impound all animals or fowl running at large in violation of this section which may be conveniently impounded, and to hold the same until all fees and charges as are herein provided for impounding and keeping such animals are paid. 
(c)  Fee. The chief of police shall be entitled to charge in each case an impounding fee of $50.00 for each goat, swine, cow, horse, mule or other livestock and $20.00 per day for each animal for keeping and impounding such animal or animals. 
(d)  Notice of sale of impounded livestock. 
(1)  Upon the impounding of any livestock by the chief of police, the chief shall forthwith serve written notice upon the owner, advising such owner of the location or place where the livestock is being held and impounded, of the amount due by reason of such impounding, and that unless such livestock be redeemed within three days from date thereof that the same shall be offered for sale. 
(2)  In the event the owner of such livestock is unknown or cannot be found, service upon the owner shall be obtained by once publishing a notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, or if there be no such newspaper then by posting of the notice at the city hall door and at two other conspicuous places within the city. Such notice shall be in substantially the following form: 
To Whom It May Concern: 
You are hereby notified that the following described livestock (giving full and accurate description of same, including marks and brands) is now impounded at (giving location where livestock is impounded) and the amount due by reason of such impounding is ____________ dollars. The above described livestock will, unless redeemed within three days from date hereof, be offered for sale at public auction to the highest and best bidder for cash. 
_____
(Date) _____
(Chief of Police)  
(3)  Unless the impounded livestock is redeemed within three days from the date of notice, the chief of police shall forthwith give notice of sale thereof which shall be held not less than five days nor more than ten days (excluding Sundays and holidays) from the first publication of the notice of sale. Said notice of sale shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city and by posting a copy of such notice at the city hall door, or if there be no such newspaper then by posting such copy at the city hall door and at two other conspicuous places in the city. Such notice of sale shall be in substantially the following form: 
(Name of owner, if known, otherwise "To Whom It May Concern") you are hereby notified that I will offer for sale and sell at public sale to the highest and best bidder for cash the following described livestock (giving full and accurate description of each head of livestock) at ____________ o'clock,   ; m. (the hour of sale to be between 11:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. Eastern Standard Time) on the ____________ day of ____________ at the following place ____________ (which place shall be where the livestock is impounded or at the place provided by the city council for the taking up and keeping of such livestock) to satisfy a claim in the sum of ____________ for fees, expenses for feeding and care and costs thereof. 
_____
(Date) _____
(Chief of Police)  
(e)  Interference with impoundment. No person shall break open or assist in the breaking open of any of the fences, gates, fastenings or enclosures of impounding vehicles and no unauthorized person shall remove or let loose any animal from the shelter or impounding vehicles or attempt to do so or in any manner interfere with such animal, or with the safe keeping thereof, until after such animal is released in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1957, §§ 4-2-4-5, 4-19; Code 1982, §§ 5-21-5-25) 
State Law reference- Livestock at large, F.S. § 588.12 et seq.; authority to impound livestock running at large or strays, F.S. § 588.16; notice of impoundment, F.S. § 588.17; fees for impoundment of livestock, F.S. § 588.18; interference with impoundment, F.S. § 588.24. 
Sec. 18-5. - Rabies vaccination of dogs, cats and ferrets. 
(a)  Vaccination required. No person shall own or harbor any dog, cat, or ferret over four months of age within the city unless such dog, cat or ferret is vaccinated. The provisions of this section do not apply to animals owned by a licensed research facility or held in a veterinary medical facility or government operated or licensed animal shelter. 
(b)  Method of vaccination. All dogs, cats and ferrets shall be vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian, in accordance with the latest "Compendium of Animal Rabies Vaccines and Recommendations for Immunization" published by the National Association of State Public Health Veterinarians. 
(c)  Certificate of vaccination. A certificate of vaccination shall be issued to the owner of each animal vaccinated on a form which must contain the following information: 
(1)  The license number of the administering veterinarian. 
(2)  The name, address, and phone number of the veterinarian and owner. 
(3)  The date of vaccination. 
(4)  The expiration date of the vaccination. 
(5)  The species, age, sex, color, breed, weight, and name of the animal vaccinated. 
(6)  The rabies vaccine manufacturer. 
(7)  The vaccine lot number and expiration date. 
(8)  The type and brand of vaccine used. 
(9)  The route of administration of the vaccine. 
(10)  The signature or signature stamp of the licensed veterinarian. 
(Code 1982, § 5-42(a)-(c); Ord. of 1-7-1986, § 2) 
State Law reference- Rabies vaccination of dogs, cats and ferrets, F.S. § 828.30. 
Secs. 18-6-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 18-31. - Animal control board. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby created the Monticello Animal Control Board. 
(b)  Composition. The board shall be comprised of three members, at least one of whom shall be a member of the Jefferson County Humane Society and one of whom shall be a certified law enforcement officer with K-9 experience. 
(c)  Appointment and term of members. The members of the board shall be appointed by the city council and shall serve for an initial period of three years, subject to reappointment for additional terms of three years at the discretion of the city council. 
(d)  Duties; compensation of members. The board shall be responsible for conducting hearings under the provisions of section 18-68, and such other duties as may be assigned to it by the city council. Members shall not receive a salary. 
(e)  Adoption of rules of procedure. The board shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business, including conducting hearings, to the extent such rules are not inconsistent with the provisions of section 18-68. Such rules may be adopted by the board without amendment of this section. 
(Ord. No. 98-07, § 5-10, 7-7-1998) 
Sec. 18-32. - Right of entry. 
    For the purposes of discharging the duties imposed by this chapter, including investigation of possible violations and for enforcing its provisions, the impounding officer or the county health officer is empowered to enter without authority of any court of competent jurisdiction upon any private property, not including any dwelling house or structure or fenced enclosure, and, but not by way of limitation, to demand that any animal or, if applicable, the license tag of such animal be exhibited to said officer, provided the impounding officer or the county health officer shall be empowered to enter into any such fenced enclosure to impound any animal known or suspected of biting or scratching any person or any animal infected with or showing suspicious symptoms of rabies. 
(Code 1957, § 4-18; Code 1982, § 5-1) 
State Law reference- Owner's liability when dog bites any person, F.S. § 767.04. 
Sec. 18-33. - Interference with authorized personnel. 
    No person shall interfere with, hinder or molest any police officer, health officer or impounding officer in the performance of any duty required by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1957, § 4-19; Code 1982, § 5-2) 
Secs. 18-34-18-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS AND CATS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, adopted May 6, 2014, amended Art. III in it's entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 18-61-18-94, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1982, §§ 5-41-5-49, 5-61-5-63; an ordinance adopted Jan. 7, 1986, §§ 1-9, 14-16; Ord. No. 98-07, § 5-26, adopted July 7, 1998. 
State Law reference- Damage by dogs, F.S. ch. 767. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means a dog or cat. 
    Animal control authority. The city manager is authorized, empowered and directed to appoint and employ a person or persons of and for the city, as enforcement officers for this chapter. 
    Animal shelter means a facility designated or recognized by the city for the purpose of impounding and caring for animals. 
    At large. A dog or cat shall be deemed to be at large when off the property of the owner and not under restraint. 
    Direct control shall be defined as immediate and continuous physical control of a dog or cat at all times such as by means of a fence, leash, cord or chain of sufficient strength to restrain the same; or in the case of specially trained or hunting animals which immediately respond to such commands, direct control shall also include aural or oral control, if the controlling person is at all times clearly and fully within the unobstructed sight and hearing of the animal. 
    Humane manner means care of an animal, to include, but not be limited to, adequate heat, ventilation and sanitary shelter, wholesome food and water, consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species and breed. 
    Neutered means rendered permanently incapable of reproduction. 
    Nuisance dog or cat. A dog or cat shall be considered a nuisance if it: 
(1)  Damages, soils, defiles, or defecates on private property other than the owner's or on public walks and recreation areas unless such waste is immediately removed and properly disposed of by the owner; 
(2)  Causes insanitary, dangerous, or offensive conditions; 
(3)  Causes a disturbance by excessive barking or other noisemaking; or 
(4)  Chases vehicles, or molests, attacks, or interferes with persons or other domestic animals on public property or private property. 
    Owner/custodian means a person, firm, corporation, partnership, trust, estate, business, or other legal entity, having the right of property or custody of a dog or cat or who keeps or harbors a dog or cat or knowingly permits a dog or cat to remain on or about any premises occupied by that person. In the case the owner is under eighteen (18) years of age, that person's parent or legal guardian will be responsible. 
    Person means any individual, corporation, partnership, organization, or institution commonly recognized by law as a unit. 
    Restraint. A dog or cat shall be considered under restraint if it is within the real property limits of its owner or secured by a leash or lead or under the control of a responsible person. 
    Vicious animal means a dog or cat that constitutes a physical threat to humans or other domestic animals. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 18-62. - Registration required for dogs and cats which have not been identified with a radio frequency identification (RFID) chip. 
(a)  No person shall own or harbor any dog or cat over four months of age within the city unless such dog or cat has received a rabies vaccination in accordance with state law and has been implanted with a RFID chip or otherwise identified with a city-issued registration tag to be worn on a collar at all times. The provisions of this section do not apply to animals owned by a licensed research facility or held in a veterinary medical facility or government operated or licensed animal shelter. 
(b)  A city-issued registration tag shall be issued upon payment of a fee to be set by resolution of the city council. 
(c)  City-issued registration tags must be attached to the collar of the dog or cat. Tags must be worn at all times and are not transferable. The city shall maintain a record of all registration tags issued. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 18-63. - Restraint required; confinement and restraint of dangerous animals; nuisance animals. 
(a)  All dogs and cats shall be kept under direct control of the owner/custodian. 
(b)  The confinement and restraint of dangerous or aggressive animals within the city is governed by the provisions of chapter 8, article II, dangerous animals and rabies control, of the Jefferson County, Florida, Code of Ordinances. 
(c)  No dog or cat shall be allowed to cause a nuisance. The owner of every dog or cat shall be held responsible for every behavior of such dog or cat under the provisions of this article. 
(d)  Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall be deemed to be a misdemeanor of the second degree and punishable as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 5-6-2014; Ord. No. 2015-05, § 2, 12-1-2015) 
Sec. 18-64. - Interference with enforcement. 
(a)  No person shall interfere with, hinder, or molest any agent of the city in the performance of any duty as herein provided. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be deemed guilty of a second degree misdemeanor and shall be subject to penalties as set forth in F.S. § 775.15. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 18-65. - Dangerous dogs. 
    The classification and control of dangerous and aggressive animals is governed by the provisions of chapter 8, article II, dangerous animals and rabies control, of the Jefferson County, Florida, Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 5-6-2014; Ord. No. 2015-05, § 3, 12-1-2015) 
Secs. 18-66-18-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 18-91. - Generally. 
(a)  Any dog or cat found running at large shall be impounded by the city animal control authority in an animal shelter and confined in a humane manner. Immediately upon impounding a dog or cat, the city animal control authority shall make every reasonable effort to identify the animal's owner by microchip or by the city-issued registration tag and inform such owner of the conditions whereby custody of the animal may be regained after payment of impoundment fees and any applicable boarding, transport or treatment or vaccination fees. 
(b)  No animal impounded by the city shall be released until proof of rabies vaccination is provided and verified by city personnel. 
(c)  Dogs and cats not claimed by their owners within a period of five business days shall become the property of the city, and may be adopted, fostered, transferred or euthanized, except animals that are unweaned, impounded as part of a litter, or are feral are not required to be held unless they are wearing identification, are microchipped, or otherwise marked in a manner that suggests they may be owned. 
(d)  No at large unaltered dog or cat impounded more than twice in an eighteen-month period may be redeemed by any person until the animal is spayed or neutered. The sterilization shall be accomplished by transporting the animal, by animal control personnel, to any duly-licensed veterinarian in Jefferson County. In all cases, the animal's owner shall not hold liable the City of Monticello or the city council members, individually or in their official capacity, and all members of the animal control authority, individually and in their official capacity, and all of the city's employees, appointees, contractors, subcontractors, and agents from any and all liability, for any and all claims, causes of action, demands or damages, and costs (to include reasonable attorney fees) present, past and future, contingent or otherwise, arising from the spay or neuter of such dog or cat. The owner is responsible to pay the veterinarian fees prior to redemption. 
(e)  In the event that the animal control officer finds dogs or cats to be neglected, suffering, or maintained without access to shelter for protection against inclement weather, he/she shall have the right forthwith to remove or cause to be removed any such animals to a safe place for care at the owner's expense or to euthanize them when necessary to prevent further suffering. Return of the animal to the owner may be withheld until the owner shall have made full payment for all impoundment and treatment expenses so incurred and provided proof of a safe premises for housing of the animal. Disposal of an animal by any method specified herein does not relieve the owner of liability for violations and any accrued charges. 
(f)  The charges or fees for impounding, keeping, or treating of any animal in city custody shall be set by the city council by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Sec. 18-92. - Adoption of impounded animals. 
    At the discretion of the animal control authority, unclaimed impounded dogs and cats may be released for adoption as a pet to members of the public. No dog or cat shall be released for adoption as a pet without being neutered, microchipped, and vaccinated against rabies. Rabies vaccination fees, neutering fees, microchip implant fees and veterinary costs may be assessed, as well as an adoption fee, to be determined by city council resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 5-6-2014) 
Chapter 22 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to adopt building, plumbing, electrical, gas, etc., codes, F.S. § 163.295; adoption of building code required, F.S. § 553.73; enforcement of building code required, F.S. § 553.80; contracting, F.S. ch. 489. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-4 of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 6-17) 
Sec. 22-2. - Permit fee; restriction on issuance of permits. 
    Any permit required by the building code is to be issued without charge, upon application therefor, provided that the city clerk is not authorized to issue a permit to any contractor who does not have a proper license from the city. 
(Code 1957, § 6-7; Code 1982, § 6-18) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to license construction contractors, F.S. § 489.131. 
Sec. 22-3. - Permit for electrical work. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any alteration in the wiring of any building for light, heat or power, or to wire any building for electric lights, motors or heating devices, within the limits of the city, without a written permit from the city clerk. 
(Code 1957, § 6-3; Code 1982, § 6-1) 
Sec. 22-4. - Placement, set-up and occupancy of preowned mobile homes. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    New mobile or modular homes, which shall be exempt from this section, means any mobile or modular home where the certificate of title indicates that the current owner is the original titleholder, exclusive of the manufacturer or licensed dealer; and where the certificate of title indicates the unit was purchased within five years of the date of inspection. However, new mobile or modular homes shall not be exempt from skirting requirements as hereinafter described. 
    Preowned mobile or modular home means any mobile or modular home where the certificate of title issued by Florida or other state of origin indicates that the current owner is not the original owner, exclusive of the manufacturer or licensed dealer. 
(b)  Standards. Effective immediately, the following rules and regulations shall apply to the set-up and occupancy of all preowned mobile or modular homes. Prior to introduction of city utilities to any preowned mobile or modular home lawfully permitted in the city, the building inspector shall inspect and certify such home and deliver to the occupant or owner a certificate of compliance with this section. Such certificate shall be issued after inspection of the following specific areas: 
(1)  The home must be free of holes, cracks or openings which would admit rain; 
(2)  Insulation systems must be in place beneath the floor, properly secured and free from apparent leaks and damage; 
(3)  The frame must be free of any indications of water damage, rot or obvious structural insufficiency; 
(4)  Ceilings must be watertight and without evidence of water damage or rot; 
(5)  Electrical systems must be safe and free of exposed wiring, unsafe outlets or fuse storage boxes. If electrical wiring is aluminum, the owner or occupant must obtain and furnish the inspection official with a certificate from a licensed electrician attesting to the safe condition of said wiring; 
(6)  Exterior steps must be in place at all entrances at least as wide as the door, with a hand rail if more than two steps. Three steps are required if the door threshold is in excess of 20 inches from the ground or concrete pad; 
(7)  Skirting must be placed between the ground or concrete pad and the exterior flooring of the mobile or modular home, and must be of sufficient strength to prevent access by animals or children, but shall allow adequate ventilation to pass beneath the home. Skirting may be constructed of wood, masonry, vinyl, lattice work or such other material as is sufficient to comply with this provision; 
(8)  Air conditioning and heating duct systems must be elevated from the ground and be free of "kinks" or bends which would obstruct air flow. Heating systems must be properly vented and in satisfactory working order; 
(9)  Window and door hardware must be operable and windows must be screened; and 
(10)  All mobile or modular homes must be located within the appropriate setbacks as mandated by the land development regulations (chapter 54). 
(c)  Inspection; certificate of compliance. 
(1)  Each preowned mobile or modular home introduced into the city must be inspected and the owner or occupant must obtain a certificate or sticker from the building inspector, or his/her designated official, certifying that such home meets all requirements of this section. Such sticker shall be valid for two years from the date of inspection and shall entitle the owner or occupant to immediate hook up to city utilities. 
(2)  If the preowned mobile or modular home fails to satisfactorily pass inspection or contains any deficiency identified herein, the building inspector shall notify the owner or occupant in writing of the specific deficiency and shall withhold issuance of a certificate pending compliance. 
(3)  There shall be a fee of $15.00 for inspection, which fee shall be payable in advance and deposited into the regular accounts of the city. Any preowned mobile or modular home which fails such inspection shall be noted by the building inspector by name, brand and serial number, which information shall be filed with the city clerk, who shall maintain a record of inspections and certificates issued. 
(4)  The building inspector may, from time to time, reinspect a home for which a certificate has previously been issued, upon reliable information that such home no longer meets the requirements of this section, and may, as necessary, recertify such home pursuant to the procedures herein set forth. 
(d)  Nonconforming uses. Existing preowned mobile or modular homes which are currently used and occupied within the city and which fail to qualify within the requirements of this section are declared to be nonconforming uses. The city council hereby declares a six-month moratorium for compliance purposes so that all existing preowned mobile or modular homes may be brought into full compliance with this section. After January 1, 1994, each mobile or modular home within the city, excluding newly purchased homes, shall bear a current and valid certificate and/or sticker certifying compliance. 
(e)  Penalty; additional remedies. 
(1)  Any firm, corporation, individual or other legal entity occupying, leasing or renting for human occupancy any mobile or modular home, in violation of this section, shall be deemed guilty of a second degree misdemeanor and shall, upon affidavit of the building inspector, be charged with this offense and, if proven, be punished in accordance with section 1-4 of this Code. 
(2)  In addition to the criminal penalties provided, the city shall have the right to seek a declaration from the circuit court that any nonconforming use, whether by owner or occupant, is a continuing violation of this section, is a sanitary nuisance, and is subject to appropriate sanctions, including injunctive relief, permanent condemnation, damages and reasonable court costs and attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 93-04, § 6-61, 5-4-1993) 
Sec. 22-5. - Floodplain management regulations-Part 1. 
    Section 104.10.1 Florida Building Code, Building - Modifications of the strict application of the requirements of the Florida Building Code. The Building Official shall coordinate with the Floodplain Administrator to review requests submitted to the Building Official that seek approval to modify the strict application of the flood resistant construction requirements of the Florida Building Code to determine whether such requests require the granting of a variance pursuant to Section 117. 
107.6.1 Building permits issued on the basis of an affidavit. Pursuant to the requirements of federal regulation for participation in the National Flood Insurance Program (44 C.F.R. Sections 59 and 60), the authority granted to the Building Official to issue permits, to rely on inspections, and to accept plans and construction documents on the basis of affidavits and plans submitted pursuant to Section 105.14 and Section 107.6, shall not extend to the flood load and flood resistance construction requirements of the Florida Building Code. 
117 VARIANCES IN FLOOD HAZARD AREAS 
117.1 Flood hazard areas. Pursuant to section 553.73(5), F.S., the variance procedures adopted in the local floodplain management ordinance shall apply to requests submitted to the Building Official for variances to the provisions of Section 1612.4 of the Florida Building Code, Building or, as applicable, the provisions of R322 of the Florida Building Code, Residential. This section shall not apply to Section 3109 of the Florida Building Code, Building. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 22-6. - Floodplain management regulations-Part 2. 
    Section 1612.4.1, Florida Building Code, Building - Elevation requirements. The minimum elevation requirements shall be as specified in ASCE 24 or the base flood elevation plus 2 feet (610 mm), whichever is higher. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 1-7-2014) 
Sec. 22-7. - Floodplain management regulations-Part 3. 
    Section R322.2.1, Florida Building Code, Residential - Elevation requirements. 
1.  Buildings and structures in flood hazard areas not designated as Coastal A Zones shall have the lowest floors elevated to or above the base flood elevation plus 2 feet or the design flood elevation, whichever is higher. 
2.  Buildings and structures in flood hazard areas designated as Coastal A Zones shall have the lowest floors elevated to or above the base flood elevation plus 2 feet 1 foot (305 mm), or to the design flood elevation, whichever is higher. 
3.  In areas of shallow flooding (AO Zones), buildings and structures shall have the lowest floor (including basement) elevated at least as high above the highest adjacent grade as the depth number specified in feet on the FIRM plus 2 feet, or at least 4 feet 2 feet (610 mm) if a depth number is not specified. 
4.  Basement floors that are below grade on all sides shall be elevated to or above the base flood elevation plus 2 feet or the design flood elevation, whichever is higher. 
Exception: Enclosed areas below the design flood elevation, including basements whose floors are not below grade on all sides, shall meet the requirements of Section R322.2.2. 
(Ord. No. 2013-14, § 3, 1-7-2014) 
Secs. 22-8-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLUMBING 

Sec. 22-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Human excreta means the bowel and kidney discharge of human beings. 
    Sanitary water closet means any flush toilet which is properly connected with the city sewer or a septic tank of approved design. 
    Septic tank means an underground cavity with watertight walls and floor into which flows the effluvia of sanitary water closets and from which the effluvia does not come to the surface of the ground but is absorbed by an arrangement of drain tile directly into the soil. 
(Code 1957, § 11-17(1)-(4); Code 1982, § 6-31) 
State Law reference- State public health rules, F.S. § 381.031. 
Sec. 22-32. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any plumbing of any character, make any change to or extension of or disconnect plumbing, or change the location of any fixture (except repairs of leaks, the opening up of stoppages and replacing of broken fixtures) within the limits of the city, without a written permit from the city clerk. 
(Code 1957, § 6-4; Code 1982, § 6-32) 
State Law reference- Cities to provide for construction of plumbing, F.S. § 469.05. 
Sec. 22-33. - Disposal of human excreta. 
(a)  Every residence and building in which human beings reside, are employed or congregate shall be required to have a sanitary method of disposing of human excreta, namely, either a sanitary water closet that is connected with the city sewer or an approved type of septic tank. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of human excreta within the corporate limits of the city except in a sanitary water closet. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or leasing any premises in the city to permit the disposal of any human excreta on any property leased or rented by any such person or the agent of any such person, except in a sanitary water closet. 
(d)  The cost of installing a sanitary water closet for the disposal of human excreta shall be borne by the owner of the property upon which the sanitary water closet is to be located. 
(Code 1957, §§ 11-18-11-21; Code 1982, §§ 6-33-6-36) 
Sec. 22-34. - Septic tanks. 
    No septic tanks other than those approved by the state department of health and rehabilitative services shall be constructed within the corporate limits of the city, nor shall such septic tanks be constructed without permits secured from the city clerk and an inspection made before the tank and the drain field are covered. 
(Code 1957, § 11-22; Code 1982, § 6-37) 
Secs. 22-35-22-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LANDLORD AND TENANT REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Landlord and tenant, F.S. ch. 83. 

Sec. 22-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building, housing and health codes means any law, ordinance or governmental regulation concerning health, safety, sanitation or fitness for habitation, or the construction, maintenance, operation, occupancy, use or appearance of any dwelling unit. 
    Landlord means the owner or lessor of a dwelling unit. 
    Premises means a dwelling unit and the structure of which it is a part and a mobile home lot and the appurtenant facilities and grounds, areas, facilities and property held out for the use of tenants generally. 
    Rental agreement means any written agreement, or oral agreement if for less duration than one year, providing for use and occupancy of premises. 
    Tenant means any person entitled to occupy a dwelling unit under a rental agreement. 
(Code 1982, § 11-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 83.43. 
Sec. 22-62. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to require minimum compliance by landlords of the standards mentioned herein which the city council has enacted and declared to be essential to the health, safety and welfare of its citizens occupying housing units as tenants or renters. 
(Code 1982, § 11-17; Ord. of 2-7-1978) 
Sec. 22-63. - Violations generally. 
(a)  Violations of this article as verified by the appropriate state agency shall render the landlord subject to arrest and prosecution. 
(b)  Furthermore, the premises wherein continued violations are found to exist shall subject the property to an order of closing by the city council until such time as full compliance is had. 
(Code 1982, § 11-18; Ord. of 2-7-1978) 
State Law reference- Remedies generally under Residential Landlord and Tenant Act, F.S. § 83.54 et seq.; injunctions, F.S. ch. 60. 
Sec. 22-64. - Injunctive relief. 
    The city may enforce this article by injunctive relief from the circuit court of the county. In that event, the city shall, upon successful prosecution, be entitled to costs and attorney's fees assessed against the violator. 
(Code 1982, § 11-19; Ord. of 2-7-1978) 
State Law reference- Remedies generally under Residential Landlord and Tenant Act, F.S. § 83.54 et seq.; injunctions, F.S. ch. 60. 
Sec. 22-65. - Maintenance responsibilities of landlord. 
(a)  The landlord at all times during the tenancy shall: 
(1)  Comply with the requirements of applicable building, housing and health codes; or 
(2)  Where there are no applicable building, housing or health codes, maintain foundations and all other structural components in good repair and capable of resisting normal forces and loads and the plumbing in reasonable working condition. However, the landlord shall not be required to maintain a mobile home or other structure owned by the tenant. 
(b)  The landlord's obligations under this section may be altered or modified in writing with respect to a single-family home or duplex. 
(Code 1982, § 11-20; Ord. of 2-7-1978) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 83.51. 
Sec. 22-66. - Additional requirements for multifamily units. 
(a)  Unless otherwise agreed in writing, in addition to the requirements of section 22-65, the landlord of a dwelling unit other than a single-family home or duplex shall, at all times during the tenancy, make reasonable provisions for: 
(1)  The extermination of rats, mice, roaches, ants, wood-destroying organisms, and bedbugs. When vacation of the premises is required for such extermination, the landlord shall not be liable for damages but shall abate the rent. The tenant shall be required to temporarily vacate the premises for a period of time not to exceed four days, on seven days' written notice, if necessary, for extermination pursuant to this subsection. 
(2)  Locks and keys. 
(3)  The clean and safe condition of common areas. 
(4)  Garbage removal and outside receptacles therefor. 
(5)  Functioning facilities for heat during winter, running water and hot water. 
(b)  Nothing in this article authorizes the tenant to raise a noncompliance by the landlord with this section as a defense to an action for possession. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to a mobile home owned by a tenant. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this section prohibits the landlord from providing in the rental agreement that the tenant is obligated to pay costs or charges for garbage removal, water, fuel or utilities. 
(Code 1982, § 11-21; Ord. of 2-7-1978) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 83.51. 
Sec. 22-67. - Conflicting provisions. 
    If the duty imposed by section 22-65 is the same as or greater than any duty imposed by section 22-66, the landlord's duty is determined by section 22-65. 
(Code 1982, § 11-22; Ord. of 2-7-1978) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 83.51. 
Sec. 22-68. - Conditions created or caused by tenant. 
    The landlord is not responsible to the tenant under this article for conditions created or caused by the negligent or wrongful act or omission of the tenant, a member of his/her family or other person on the premises with his/her consent. 
(Code 1982, § 11-23; Ord. of 2-7-1978) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 83.51. 
Secs. 22-69-22-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DILAPIDATED DWELLINGS AND STRUCTURES 

Sec. 22-101. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and cited as the "City of Monticello Condemnation of Dilapidated Dwellings and Structures Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-102. - Authority. 
    The City of Monticello, by virtue of its charter and by virtue of the general laws of Florida, declares there is an immediate need to remove unsafe and unsightly dwelling units and structures within the city and to provide a method for demolition, if necessary, this article is enacted for these and other pertinent purposes. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-103. - Designation of unfit dwelling units and structures. 
(a)  Grounds. Any dwelling or dwelling unit or commercial structure having the following defects, may be designated by the building inspector and city superintendent jointly as unfit for human habitation or commercial use and they may so placard it on two prominent locations by posting thereon a cardboard notice containing the words "Condemned by the City of Monticello. No Trespassing." 
(1)  The structure lacks illumination, ventilation, sanitation, heat, inadequate or unsafe wiring or other facilities adequate to protect the health and safety of the occupants or the public. 
(2)  The structure is damaged, decayed, dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe or vermin infested in such manner as to create a serious hazard to the health and safety of the occupants or the public and/or has become a location of repeated criminal activity. 
(3)  The structure, because of the location, general condition, state of the premises or number of occupants, is so unsanitary, unsafe, overcrowded or otherwise detrimental to health and safety that it creates a serious hazard to the occupants or the public. 
(4)  The structure, because of the failure of the owner or occupant to comply with such prior notices or orders issued pursuant to this article, is unfit for human habitation. 
(b)  Notice. Whenever the building inspector and city superintendent, or their duly designated representatives, determine that a dwelling or structure is unfit for human habitation, as provided in subsection (a) above, they shall include such findings within the notice of violation provided in subsection (a) above relating to notices and orders and they shall also include a statement of their intent to vacate and placard the dwelling unit or structure if compliance with the provisions of the notice of violation has not been secured. 
(c)  Order to vacate. Whenever a notice of violation, as provided in subsection (b) above, has not been complied with or a hearing on the violation has not been invoked as provided for in section 27-7 hereof, the building inspector and city superintendent may order the dwelling or dwelling unit or structure to be vacated. A copy of such notice to vacate shall be served on the owner or occupant as provided for in section 27-7 hereof. 
(d)  Vacated dwelling made secure. The owner, agent or operator of any dwelling or commercial structure which has been designated as unfit for human habitation or commercial use and ordered vacated, shall make such dwelling safe and secure in whatever manner the building inspector and city superintendent shall deem necessary in order to meet the standards set forth herein. Any vacated building open at the doors and windows, if unguarded, shall be deemed dangerous to human life and a nuisance within the meaning of this provision. 
(e)  Notice of intent to demolish. Whenever the building inspector and city superintendent designate a building unfit for human habitation, as provided in this article, and determine that the cost necessary to correct the violation is not reasonably related to the value of the building, they shall include within the notice of violation a statement of their intent to order the demolition of the building. A copy of such notice shall be served on the owner, occupant, lessee, or mortgagee. The owner may demolish the building or correct the violation regardless of cost, provided the requirements of the building code are satisfied. Demolition by the owner shall constitute compliance. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-104. - Responsibility of occupant. 
    The responsibilities of the occupant are as follows: 
(1)  To keep dwelling or structure and premises he controls and occupies in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(2)  To dispose of rubbish and garbage in a clean and sanitary manner as prescribed by city ordinances or regulations. 
(3)  To hang and remove screens provided by the owner except where owner has agreed to supply such services. 
(4)  To keep plumbing fixtures therein in a clean and sanitary condition and to exercise reasonable care in the proper use and operation thereof. 
(5)  To exterminate in the following cases: 
a.  Occupant of a single dwelling is responsible for extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein or on premises. 
b.  Occupant of a dwelling unit in a multiple unit structure is responsible for extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests, if his unit is the only unit infested. 
Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this section, whenever infestation is caused by the failure of owner to maintain the dwelling in a ratproof or reasonably insect proof condition, the occupant is not resonsible for extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-105. - Responsibilities of owner. 
    The responsibilities of the owner are as follows: 
(1)  To let no dwelling to any one for an occupancy unless it meets minimum standards set forth herein. 
(2)  To have dwelling in clean, sanitary, habitable condition, to free from infestation before renting, to paint walls and ceilings and to clean, repair and exterminate if needed to meet aforesaid requirements before offering for rent. 
(3)  To provide screens to be hung. 
(4)  To exterminate in the following cases: 
a.  When infestation exists in two or more units or multiple unit structures. 
b.  When infestation exists in shared or public areas of multiple unit structure. 
c.  When infestation exists in single unit of multiple unit structure or in single unit structure when infestation is due to failure of the owner to maintain the dwelling in a ratproof and reasonably insect proof condition. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-106. - Minimum standards-General condition of structures. 
(a)  All dwelling structures shall be watertight, weatherproof, rodent and insect proof and in good repair. 
(b)  Every foundation, exterior wall and roof shall be reasonably watertight, weathertight and rodent proof, shall adequately support the building at all times and shall be in a workmanlike state of maintenance and repair. 
(c)  Every interior partition, wall, floor and ceiling shall be reasonably tight, capable of affording privacy and maintained in a workmanlike state of repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-107. - Hearings and appeals-City council authority. 
(a)  Should the owner of a dwelling unit or structure, or occupant thereof, disagree with the findings of the building inspector and city superintendent that a dwelling unit or commercial structure is subject to condemnation and demolition, or is unfit for human habitation, any such person may, within 15 days of receipt of said notice, request in writing a hearing on the sufficiency of the evidence relied upon by said building inspector and city superintendent. The city council shall promptly schedule a hearing on the issues in dispute and shall hear evidence regarding the existence of or extent of those conditions which give rise to the decision of said officials. Once the request is received by the city clerk, said clerk shall notify all interested persons and no demolition or order to vacate shall be initiated or continued until the city council resolves the issues in dispute. 
(b)  The city council shall allow at least 15 days prior to scheduling a hearing but the hearing shall, in no event, be scheduled for more than 45 following the request for hearing. 
(c)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the city council shall, by written order, uphold the decision to condemn and demolish or, in the absence of sufficient evidence to support the condemnation and demolition, vacate and overrule any prior notices or orders for demolition. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-108. - Lien for costs of demolition. 
    Upon completion of demolition of any dwelling unit or structure, the city clerk shall notify the owner at his last known address of the completion of demolition and shall enclose a statement for costs for such demolition, payable in 30 days. Should such billing remain unpaid for 60 days after notice, the city may file a claim of lien as provided by law and enforce payment accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-109. - Method of demolition; public uses of refuse; right to promote fire fighter training by controlled burning. 
    Whenever a dwelling unit or structure has been duly condemned and notice of intent to demolish has been served and the owner has failed to comply with the required notices regarding correction and repair, the city shall proceed to demolish said premises in a method deemed appropriate by the city superintendent and/or building inspector. The city council hereby declares the use of fire fighters or trainees in a controlled burn of said property shall be an acceptable method of demolition. Prior or subsequent to such demolition by burning or any other acceptable means, the city shall retain the right of salvage for any property usable by the city in any of its departments for public use. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 22-110. - Subsequent building permits. 
    No owner or partial owner or legal successor to owner or part owner whose property has been demolished, shall be entitled to a building permit in any location within the city limits until such time as the costs and lien for previous demolition is fully paid and discharged and release of lien filed with the clerk. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, 6-5-1990) 
Chapter 26 - BUSINESSES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS TAX RECEIPTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, adopted Dec. 1, 2009, amended Art. II, in its entirety, to read as herein set out. Formerly, said article pertained to occupational license tax and derived from §§ 12-1, 12-3-12-10, 12-19-12-21, 12-23, 12-33, and 12-34 of the Code of 1957, Ord. of 8-21-1979, §§ 12-1-12-16, 12-31 and 12-32 of the Code of 1982, Ord. No. 98-05, adopted July 7, 1998, Ord. No. 2004-04, § 1(12-4), adopted Sept. 7, 2004, and Ord. No. 2004-06, § 1(12-17), adopted Sept. 7, 2004. 

Sec. 26-31. - Payment of a business tax is required to engage in business, profession or occupation; issuance. 
    No person shall engage in or manage any business, profession or occupation mentioned in this chapter within the city until after a business tax receipt has been procured from the city, which business tax receipt shall be issued to each person on payment of the amount hereinafter provided, paid to the city clerk, who shall issue all business tax receipts. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
Sec. 26-32. - Due date; proration. 
(a)  All business tax receipts issued under this chapter shall be due and payable on October 1 of each year, and no business tax receipt shall be issued for a fractional portion of a year; except that a business tax receipt may be issued after April 1 upon payment of one-half the amount fixed as the price of such tax for one year. 
(b)  The city shall not contract for goods or services, nor expend any funds with any individual, firm or other entity which is delinquent in payment of its business tax for the current year or any past years, according to the books and records in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Further, should any payments be due to any business for past services rendered or goods provided to the city, no payment, fee, or commission shall be issued until all past due business taxes, together with any penalties, have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. §§ 205.043, 205.053. 
Sec. 26-33. - Delinquent payments. 
    Those business taxes under this article which are not paid by October 1 shall be considered delinquent and subject to a delinquency penalty of ten percent for the month of October, plus an additional five percent penalty for each month of delinquency thereafter until paid. However, the total delinquency penalty shall not exceed 25 percent of the business tax for the delinquent establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.053. 
Sec. 26-34. - Penalty for doing business without license. 
    Any person engaging in or managing any business, occupation or profession without first obtaining a business tax receipt, if required under this article, shall be subject to a penalty of 25 percent of the tax determined to be due, in addition to any other penalty provided by law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.053. 
Sec. 26-35. - Payment of penalty prerequisite to issuance of business tax receipt. 
    It shall be the duty of all delinquent taxpayers as set forth in this article to pay the increased business tax to the city clerk, and the payment of such amount to him/her shall be a condition precedent to the issuance of the business tax receipt provided by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
Sec. 26-36. - Wholesalers. 
(a)  All business tax receipts issued by the city for engaging in or managing any wholesale business shall entitle the receipt holder to sell only to retail merchants possessing current business tax receipts, unless otherwise provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any wholesale dealer doing business within the limits of the city to sell or offer for sale any goods, wares or merchandise to any person except a retail merchant possessing a current business tax receipt. 
(c)  All wholesale dealers doing business within the limits of the city who shall sell or offer for sale any goods, wares or merchandise to any person within the city other than a retail merchant possessing a current business tax receipt shall be required to obtain an appropriate business tax receipt for retail trade, as provided by this article. 
(d)  Nothing contained in subsections (a) through (c) of this section shall prohibit the selling by licensed wholesale dealers in gasoline and kerosene to individuals of gasoline in lots of 50 gallons or more and of kerosene in lots of 20 gallons or more, without a business tax receipt, provided such amounts shall be delivered in one delivery, and that at no time delivery is made into the fuel tank of a motor vehicle; and provided further that at least one filling station, possessing a current business tax receipt, and doing business in the city, shall be furnished with a written notice of such transaction at the time of delivery. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
Sec. 26-37. - Posting. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons carrying on any business, profession or occupation mentioned in this article to keep their business tax receipt conspicuously posted in their place of business. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
Sec. 26-38. - Transfer. 
(a)  Transfer upon sale of business. All business tax receipts may be transferred to a new owner when there is a bona fide sale of the business upon payment of a transfer fee of $3.00 and presentation of the original business tax receipt and evidence of the sale. 
(b)  Transfer upon change of location. Upon written request and presentation of the original business tax receipt, any business tax receipt issued under this article may be transferred from one location to another location in the city upon payment of a transfer fee of $3.00. 
(c)  Effect of transfer; surrender of original license. A business tax receipt transferred under this article shall not be good for any longer time nor in any other place than that for which it was originally or subsequently issued. The original business tax receipt must be surrendered to and filed with the city clerk at the time of the application for the transfer, and such transfer, after being approved, shall be of the same force and effect as the original business tax receipt. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.043. 
Sec. 26-39. - Expiration date. 
    All business tax receipts issued under this chapter shall expire and be null and void on September 30, as of midnight, of each year. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 205.043. 
Sec. 26-40. - Failure to pay business tax. 
    Any person failing or refusing to pay a business tax according to the tax schedule then and there in effect shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree. Further, the conviction of a violation shall not relieve the person from his/her obligation to pay the tax and penalties thereon as established by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
State Law reference- Amount of penalties and fines specified, F.S. § 775.082 et seq. 
Sec. 26-41. - Sales on courthouse circle. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any items, including merchandise and agricultural produce, locally grown or otherwise, on sidewalks, parking spaces or other property abutting the courthouse circle in the city. 
(b)  Any person found in violation of this section shall be given a written warning and notice to cease and desist. Any violation after such written warning and notice to cease and desist shall, pursuant to F.S. § 162.22, be punishable as provided in section 1-4 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
Sec. 26-42. - Tax schedule. 
    The following enumerated individual business taxes shall be paid to the city yearly, unless otherwise specified, by the persons engaging in or managing or transacting the several occupations or professions named: 
ABSTRACT COMPANIES, agents, firms or persons engaged in the business of making abstracts of title from public records: $25.00

(2)  Same as above when vehicle is used: $50.00

(4)  Advertising schemes and devices not otherwise provided for, each device: $25.00 
(5)  Any person engaged in the business of outdoor advertising, such as painted walls, bulletins, spectacular electric displays, etc.: $100.00 
Provided, however, that this license tax is not intended to include signs advertising any business when painted by a licensed sign painter.)

BOATS. Keeping for hire or operating for profit, launches or other boats whether propelled by steam, electricity or other power as follows:

BONDS OR INVESTMENTS (see also BROKERS). Agents for selling or offering for sale stock or bonds which are to mature by the payment of installments or otherwise: $10.00

BUILDERS AND CONSTRUCTION COMPANIES. (See CONTRACTORS.) 
BUILDERS' SUPPLIES. Dealers in, including doors, sash and blinds, oils, mantels, lime, cement, etc. (but this shall not include factories manufacturing sash, doors, blinds or novelty works): $20.00

BUS LINE OFFICE: $25.00

COMPUTER SERVICE: $25.00 
CONTRACTORS. Persons holding themselves out as regular contractors as a business shall pay a business tax as follows: 
(1)  Paper hanging, house and sign painting, including inside painting: $10.00 
(2)  Paving and sidewalk: $10.00 
(3)  Plumbing: $10.00 
(4)  Electrical: $10.00

ARTICLE III. - AUCTIONEERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Offenses by auctioneers, F.S. § 468.381 et seq. 

Sec. 26-71. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article, an auctioneer is defined to be any person who shall sell or offer to sell any goods, wares or merchandise, livestock, or vehicles of any description or any personal property of whatever nature or any real estate or interest therein, at any store, stand or any place within the city by public outcry for gain or profit, or who shall advertise or hold himself/herself out as an auctioneer for public patronage, or shall receive fees or commission for his/her services. 
(Code 1957, § 14-12; Code 1982, § 12-86) 
Sec. 26-72. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to apply to any common carrier or public warehouseman selling unclaimed or undelivered freight or goods where the same is held for freight or storage charges, nor to any sale made under the laws of the United States, the state, or the city requiring any property to be sold at public auction. 
(Code 1957, § 14-14; Code 1982, § 12-87) 
State Law reference- Auction sale to enforce statutory lien, F.S. § 85.031; liens for recovering, towing or storing vehicles, F.S. § 713.78; auction sale for partition of property, F.S. § 64.071; tax sale of personal property, F.S. § 197.106. 
Sec. 26-73. - Bond. 
    Before the issuance of any business tax receipt to a person engaging in the business of auctioneering, the applicant shall execute and deliver to the city a bond of a surety company authorized to do business in the state in the sum of $1,000.00 conditioned on the faithful observance of the provisions of this article by the applicant and approved by the city. 
(Code 1957, § 14-13; Code 1982, § 12-88; Ord. No. 2009-07, § 2, 12-1-2009) 
Sec. 26-74. - Manner of conducting sale; refusal of bids. 
    Each article offered for sale at auction shall be sold as offered, if a bid is made by more than one bona fide bidder, before any other article is offered for sale, and without a reasonable delay. No by-bidding by the owner or any person acting for or representing the owner shall be permitted, nor shall any bid be accepted that is not a bona fide bid, and such person shall not be permitted to bid at any such auction, and there shall be no reserve price on any such article provided, however, that the seller may be a reserve price placed on any article if such fact is made known to the bidder when such article is offered for sale at auction; provided, further, that any resident of the city or establishment in possession of a current city business tax receipt may reject any and all bids. 
(Code 1957, § 14-15; Code 1982, § 12-89; Ord. No. 2009-07, § 3, 12-1-2009) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 468.388(7), (8). 
Sec. 26-75. - Sales in public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any auctioneer or other person to offer for sale, or sell at public auction or by public outcry, any goods, wares or merchandise or any livestock, or any other personal property, or any real estate or interest therein, upon any street or public place in the city, unless written permission has been obtained from the city so to do. 
(Code 1957, § 14-16; Code 1982, § 12-90) 
Secs. 26-76-26-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COIN-OPERATED DEVICES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Fraudulent operation of coin-operated devices, F.S. § 817.32; coin-operated gambling devices, F.S. §§ 849.15, 849.235; damaging vending machines, parking meters, F.S. § 877.08; slugs, F.S. § 817.33. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automatic vending machine means any machine dispensing any articles of value, uniform as to quantity and quality, upon the insertion of a coin into the machine. This definition shall not include coin-operated telephones and United States stamp vending machines. 
    Coin-operated amusement devices other than skill machines means machines which produce or reproduce music, or return entertainment or amusement for a consideration. This definition is supplemental to the definition of coin-operated skill devices as provided in this section. 
    Coin-operated skill devices (commonly called pinball, marble machines and the like) means any machines which are played strictly for amusement purposes only as games of skill, for a consideration, and which, when played or operated, do not vend, deliver or grant any merchandise, prize or award of whatsoever nature or kind. 
(Code 1957, §§ 8-1-8-3; Code 1982, § 12-101) 
State Law reference- "Coin-operated vending machine" defined, F.S. § 877.08. 
Sec. 26-102. - Exemptions. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to authorize the licensing of slot machines or other gambling machines or devices of whatever nature, nor shall the provisions of this article be applicable to stamp machines or to coin-operated telephones or to coin-operated parcel-checking locks and toilet locks or to any coin-operated machine which vends only unadulterated Florida-produced citrus juices. 
(Code 1957, § 8-12; Code 1982, § 12-102) 
State Law reference- Coin-operated gambling devices, F.S. §§ 849.15, 849.235. 
Sec. 26-103. - Inspections. 
    All machines placed in the city under this article shall be at all times subject to such inspection as may be directed by the chief of police or the mayor. 
(Code 1957, § 8-10; Code 1982, § 12-103; Ord. No. 2009-07, § 3, 12-1-2009) 
Secs. 26-104-26-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SKILL DEVICES 

Sec. 26-131. - Generally. 
    Any and all coin-operated skill devices, as defined in this article, shall be subject to the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1957, § 8-11; Code 1982, § 12-111) 
Sec. 26-132. - Location near schools or churches.
