The decision of the city designee shall be based on balancing the preservation of the more enduring tree species, inclusive of current health, size, and form and the ability to develop a site at the intensity or density permitted by the comprehensive plan and the implementing land development regulations. In cases where the applicant chooses to appeal the city designee's decision, the city council shall have the authority to conduct appeal hearings related to the decision of protected tree removal. 
(1)  Criteria for protected tree removal. The city designee shall approve a permit for removal of a protected tree if the applicant demonstrates the presence of one or more of the following conditions: 
a.  Good forestry practices. Necessity to reduce competition between trees or to remove exotic or noxious, or invasive species and replace them with native species. 
b.  Reasonable and permissible use of property. Tree removal which is essential for reasonable and permissible use of property, or necessary for construction of essential improvements resulting from: 
1.  Need for access immediately around the proposed structure for essential construction equipment, limited to a maximum width of 20 feet from the structure. 
2.  Limited access to the building site essential for reasonable use of construction equipment. 
3.  Essential grade changes. Essential grade changes are those changes needed to implement safety standards common to standard engineering or architectural practices, and reference to a text that includes such standards shall be included in the permit application. 
4.  Location of driveways, buildings or other permanent improvements. Driveway aisles shall be consistent with other applicable standards. 
5.  Compliance with other ordinances or codes. Necessity for compliance with other city or county codes, such as building, zoning, subdivision regulations, health provisions, and other environmental ordinances. 
(d)  Reforestation requirements . All sites, except for individual lots being developed with one single-family, duplex, or triplex, shall provide, upon completion of development activities, a minimum number of trees equivalent to a ratio of 40 tree credits for each acre proposed for development; i.e., total tree preservation credits plus tree replanting credits shall be equal to or greater than 40 credits per acre proposed for development (see table inset below). If the total number of trees to be replanted exceeds that which may be reasonably planted on the development site, the applicant may enter into an agreement with the city, as approved by the city designee, to plant the excess trees on an approved public site or to provide the monetary equivalent to the city for use in public landscaping projects. This option can only be utilized if the minimum reforestation requirements cannot be met on site. 
(e)  Tree protection requirements . It is the intent of this subsection to preserve the community's existing native tree canopy and vegetative understory. In order to maintain the integrity of existing trees, it is necessary to protect the root systems of individual trees that are contained within the critical protection zone from impacts associated with development activity. It is also the intent of this subsection to give priority to preserving the more enduring tree species, inclusive of current health, size and form. The following requirements shall apply: 
(1)  Critical protection zone preservation. The critical protection zone of every protected tree not permitted for removal shall be protected from activities that may injure the tree, including, but not limited to, cut and fill activities, building pad placements, road bed construction, construction material storage, driving or parking heavy equipment, or trenching. If impact to the critical protection zone occurs, the tree shall be considered removed and shall require compensation in accordance with subsections (i) below. 
(2)  Location of protected trees. All protected trees on-site and adjacent to the site, if the critical protection zone extends to within the project site, shall be physically located and depicted on the site plan submitted as part of the site review application. 
(3)  Tree protection barriers. Tree protection barriers shall be installed at the perimeter of the critical protection zone of each protected tree prior to the initiation of development activity. The barriers shall remain in place and intact until such time as approved landscape operations begin; however, barriers may be removed temporarily to accommodate construction needs, provided that the manner and purpose for such temporary removal will not harm the tree and is approved in advance by the director. The following are minimum requirements for barrier types: 
a.  Protective posts shall be placed so as to protect the critical protection zone for each tree not permitted for removal. 
b.  Posts shall be of nominal two inches by four inches or larger wooden post, two inches outer diameter or larger pipe, or other post material of equivalent size; shall be strung with at least one one-inch by four-inch (1" x 4") wooden stringer; and shall be clearly flagged. 
c.  Posts shall be implanted deep enough in the ground to be stable and to extend to a minimum height of four feet above ground. 
d.  Where the city designee determines that individual protective barriers are not needed in some areas for tree protection, such areas shall instead be clearly staked and flagged with readily visible markers. 
e.  Where development activity is permitted to occur within the critical protection zone of a protected tree, the city designee may allow the temporary removal of the perimeter tree protection barriers and shall require a protective girdling of at least the bottom four feet of the tree trunk base along with fencing or other approved techniques. Heavy mulch (which means a minimum of four inches) applied over the root zone within the critical protection zone shall be required. In heavy traffic areas, the critical protection zone shall be topped with plywood sheets (a minimum width of 1/2-inch) over the heavy mulch to distribute equipment weight. Additional mitigation measures as described in this section may be required. 
(f)  Tree protection techniques. . Tree protection techniques found in the "Trees and Development, A Technical Guide to Preservation of Trees During Land Development," by Nelda Matheny and James R. Clark or equivalent techniques approved by the city designee, shall be used and shall be indicated in the environmental management permit application or site plan. 
(g)  Tree mitigation techniques . It is the intent of this subsection to preserve mature trees and to promote tree safety. As an incentive to preserve existing trees, when the following arboricultural mitigation techniques are employed in their entirety, the city designee may defer the tree replacement requirements. No credit will be given and no debits will be charged for successfully mitigated trees. Additional mitigation techniques not specified below may be approved when supported with scientific documentation. The information shall be reviewed and approved by the city designee. The mitigation plan shall be prepared and applied and/or supervised by a landscape architect or certified arborist. If the mitigation is deemed completed by the city designee, the deferred tree replacement requirements shall be waived. 
(h)  Credit for tree preservation . Credit may be given for the preservation of an existing tree provided that the following criteria are met: 
(1)  The critical protection zone of each preserved tree shall be protected during development activities and maintained during and after development in a natural state, in a vegetative landscape material covering; 
(2)  There shall be no impervious area or grade change within the critical protection zone of the tree. The critical protection zone is defined as that area surrounding a tree within a circle described by a radius of one foot for each inch of the tree's diameter at breast height; 
(3)  The tree shall not be damaged from skinning, de-barking, bumping and the like; 
(4)  There shall be no evidence of active disease or insect infestation potentially lethal to the tree; 
(5)  Hand-clearing shall be required when necessary to remove debris, noxious or invasive vegetation; 
(6)  Tree protection requirements of this chapter are fulfilled; 
(i)  Tree debits and tree credits . Tree debits and credits are used to represent the taking or the preservation of an eight-inch diameter at breast height tree or larger. Debit for removed trees and credit for preserved trees shall be tabulated as follows: 
Calculate the number of credits for trees preserved per acre. The size (DBH) shall correspond to the number of credits within the credit column, (see chart below). Tree trunk diameter measurements shall be rounded off to the nearest inch. (Note: trees listed by the Florida Exotic Pest Plant Council in the list of invasive species shall not be included in any tabulation of debits or credits.) 
Diameter of Tree Credits 2-3 1 4-6 2 7-12 4 13-18 6 19-24 8 25-30 10 31-36 16 37-42 20 43-48 24 49-60 28 60-70 40  
(Ord. No. 2006-04, § 2, 5-2-2006) 
Chapter 58 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes, F.S. § 775.01 et seq.; criminal mischief, F.S. § 806.13; obscene literature, F.S. § 847.011 et seq.; violations of certain commercial restrictions, F.S. § 865.02 et seq. 

Sec. 58-1. - State misdemeanors adopted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit, within the limits of the city, any act which is recognized by the laws of the state as a misdemeanor. The commission of any such act in the city shall be considered a violation of the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1957, § 13-38; Code 1982, § 16-1) 
Sec. 58-2. - Placing merchandise on street or sidewalk. 
(a)  General prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed or allow to remain in front of his/her premises or place of business any goods, wares, merchandise, fruits, vegetables or articles of any description for sale or display, or any showcases, stands, boxes or containers for the display or sale of merchandise, on any sidewalk or street within the city, except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section and section 74-2 of this Code. 
(b)  Receiving and delivering goods. Merchants and others may occupy with goods, wares and merchandise portions of the sidewalks and streets for the purpose of receiving and delivering same, for such reasonable time as may be necessary for so doing, and in such manner as not to obstruct or impede the course of travel thereon. 
(c)  Christmas season. During the period between December 15 and December 31 of each year, the city council shall have the authority to grant to licensed merchants and shopkeepers the privilege of occupying a space not more than two feet wide, extending across the front of their store buildings, for the sole purpose of displaying their goods, wares and merchandise. 
(Code 1957, §§ 13-4, 13-5, 13-7; Code 1982, §§ 16-2-16-4; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 1, 10-4-2016) 
State Law reference- Offenses concerning public roads, F.S. § 861.01 et seq. 
Sec. 58-3. - Throwing stones or other missiles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw a ball, stone or other missile or cause same by any means to fly through the air on any public street or in the near proximity to any building. 
(Code 1957, § 13-12; Code 1982, § 16-5) 
State Law reference- Projecting missiles in certain locations, F.S. § 790.19. 
Sec. 58-4. - Carrying concealed weapon. 
    The carrying of a concealed weapon, other than a firearm, is hereby declared a breach of the peace and any officer authorized to make arrests under the ordinances of this city and the laws of this state is hereby authorized to make arrests without warrant of persons violating the provisions of F.S. § 790.01 when said officer has reasonable grounds or probable cause to believe that the offense of carrying a concealed weapon is being committed. 
(Code 1957, § 13-40; Code 1982, § 16-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 790.02. 
Sec. 58-5. - Discharge of air gun or slingshot. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any air gun or slingshot in the city. 
(Code 1957, § 13-15; Code 1982, § 16-7; Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, 9-6-2011) 
Sec. 58-6. - Gambling apparatus. 
    If any of the implements, devices or apparatus commonly used in games of chance in gambling houses, or by gamblers, are found in any house, room, booth, shelter or other place, it shall be prima facie evidence that the said house, room, booth, shelter or other place where the same are found is kept for the purpose of gambling. 
(Code 1957, § 13-47; Code 1982, § 16-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 849.05. 
Sec. 58-7. - Lotteries. 
(a)  Violations by agents or employees. It shall be unlawful for any person acting as servant, clerk, agent or employee of any person to violate any of the provisions of F.S. § 849.09. 
(b)  Allowing use of premises for conducting lottery. It shall be unlawful for any person, whether the owner or agent, knowingly to rent to another person a house, room, booth, tent, shelter or other place for the purpose of conducting a lottery as prohibited by F.S. § 849.09. 
(c)  Forfeiture of money and prizes. All sums of money and every other valuable thing drawn and won as a prize, or as a share of a prize, or as a share, percentage or profit of the principal promoter or operator, in any lottery, and all money, currency or property of any kind to be disposed of, or offered to be disposed of, by chance or device in any scheme or under any pretext by any person, and all sums of money or other thing of value received by any person by reason of his/her being the owner or holder of any ticket or share of a ticket in a lottery, or pretended lottery, or of a share or right in any such schemes of chance or device, and all sums of money and other thing of value used in the setting up, conducting or operation of a lottery, and all money or other thing of value at stake or used or displayed in or in connection with any illegal gambling or any illegal gambling device contrary to the laws of this state, shall be forfeited, and may be recovered by civil proceedings filed, or by action for money had and received, to be brought by the department of legal affairs or any state attorney, or other prosecuting officer, in the circuit courts in the name and on behalf of the state; the same to be applied when collected as all other penal forfeitures are disposed of. 
(d)  Seizure of apparatus. It shall be the duty of the chief of police, or of any police officer of the city, when any of the implements, devices or apparatus commonly used for conducting a lottery prohibited by F.S. § 849.09 are found in any house, room, booth or other place used for the purpose of gaming, to seize the same for disposition as provided by F.S. ch. 849. 
(Code 1957, §§ 13-42, 13-43, 13-46, 13-48; Code 1982, §§ 16-9-16-12) 
State Law reference- Lotteries, F.S. § 849.09; forfeiture of money and prizes, F.S. § 849.12; seizure and forfeiture of property used in violation, F.S. § 849.36. 
Sec. 58-8. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense under this Code for any person to disturb or endanger the public peace or decency by any disorderly conduct. 
(b)  The following acts, among others specified by law, are declared to be disorderly conduct: 
(1)  Making of any threats of violence to or against any other person. 
(2)  Being noisy and disorderly in or upon any street or other public place in the city. 
(3)  The reckless and dangerous use of slingshots. 
(Code 1957, § 13-14; Code 1982, § 16-14) 
Sec. 58-9. - Parking in commercial or shopping center parking area at night. 
(a)  Parking of motor vehicles is prohibited in parking areas of privately owned shopping centers and other commercial areas between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., except with the written permission of the owner or lessee. The city police department is empowered to issue a parking ticket and summons in the amount of $15.00 for each such violation. This section shall exclude delivery vehicles in the process of making deliveries, loading or unloading merchandise or stock to any such owner or tenant. The owner or the city police department is empowered to erect such signs as are appropriate to give notice of this section. Nothing herein shall prevent the owner or lessee from towing or removing improper vehicles, in a reasonable manner, at the expense of the violator. 
(b)  The parking of large commercial vehicles is hereby prohibited in parking areas of privately owned shopping centers and other commercial areas without prior written permission of the city police department or owner. Excluded shall be large commercial vehicles, as hereinafter defined, while loading, unloading or delivering stock or merchandise to the owner or lessee. Large commercial vehicles are defined as semi-tractor-trailers or any vehicle with an excess of four tires and commonly used as a commercial carrier. 
(Code 1982, § 16-15; Ord. No. 91-04, 5-7-1991) 
Sec. 58-10. - Loitering in commercial or shopping center parking area at night. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to be present in groups of more than two, or in motor vehicles or on motorcycles, on any privately owned shopping center or other commercial area within the parking lot, from one-half hour after closing of the last commercial business or 10:30 p.m., whichever is later. 
(b)  Excluded are persons providing lawful functions, delivering merchandise, moving stock or engaging in a lawful commercial transaction with the owner or lessee, or persons with the written permission of the owner or lessee. 
(c)  The city police department is authorized to disband such groups and direct their removal from such private property, and to issue a summons as mentioned in section 58-9. 
(Code 1982, § 16-16; Ord. No. 91-05, 5-7-1991) 
Sec. 58-11. - Excessive noise from radio or similar sound-making device-Generally. 
(a)  Prohibited noise. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or amplify the sound produced by, a radio, tape or CD player, or other mechanical, electronic or other sound-making device or instrument from which the sound: 
(1)  Is plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from the source of the sound; 
(2)  Causes serious annoyance to a neighboring resident and interferes with the reasonable use and enjoyment of his/her property; or 
(3)  Is otherwise offensive so as to create a nuisance. 
(b)  Exceptions. The provisions of this section do not apply to the operation or amplification of sound produced by a radio, tape or CD player, or other mechanical, electronic or other sound making device or instrument which is used for political or business purposes, provided such businesses use sound making devices in the normal course of conducting their business, nor shall the provisions of this section apply to the operation or amplification of sound produced by such devices for religious or educational purposes, including but not limited to, outdoor worship services and high school sporting events, nor shall the provisions apply to parades, dances, and similar public events for which the appropriate authorization (where necessary) has been obtained. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a second degree misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 2000-06, § 15-14, 8-1-2000) 
Sec. 58-12. - Same-Between 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(a)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person operating a restaurant, bar, tavern or other licensed establishment, or any person occupying a motor vehicle on a street or highway, between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., to operate or amplify the sound produced by a radio, tape player, or other mechanical sound-making device from within such structure or vehicle, so that the sound is: 
(1)  Plainly audible at a distance of 100 feet or more from the vehicle or structure; or 
(2)  Louder than necessary for the convenient hearing by persons inside the vehicle or structure. 
(b)  Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to law enforcement or emergency vehicles equipped with communication devices. This section shall not apply to motor vehicles used for business or political purposes which, in the normal course of conducting such business, use soundmaking devices. However, this exception shall not be construed to prevent local authorities, with respect to streets and highways under their jurisdiction, and within the reasonable exercise of police power, from regulating the time and manner in which such businesses may be operated. Additionally, the provisions of this section do not apply to the noise made by a horn or other warning device required or permitted by F.S. § 316.27. 
(c)  Enforcement; penalty. Any person found in violation of this section shall be given a written warning and notice to cease and desist. After such warning, and upon a first conviction, the violation shall be treated as a second degree misdemeanor and punishable pursuant to F.S. § 775.01 et seq. Upon the second conviction within 12 months of a previous conviction, the violation shall be treated as a first degree misdemeanor and punishable pursuant to F.S. § 775.01 et seq. The chief of police or any police officer of the city may effect the arrest of a violator by warrant or, if committed in the presence of such officer, without a warrant, as mandated in F.S. § 901.15. 
(Ord. No. 96-06, § 16-17, 9-5-1996) 
Sec. 58-13. - Garage sale regulations. 
(a)  Garage sale defined. The term "garage sale" as used in this section is hereby defined to mean any sale or offering for sale of personal property by a person or persons of a family or other household unit, said personal property having been acquired, possessed and used by the family or household for personal, as opposed to business or commercial use, when such sale is to be or is conducted at the residence of such family or household. "Garage sale" shall include a sale commonly referred to as a patio sale, driveway sale, yard sale and other such sales. 
(b)  No permit required. No permit shall be required by the City of Monticello for a garage sale conducted within the city pursuant to this article. No more than three garage sales may be conducted at any one residence or household during any calendar year. Garage sales shall be limited in duration to no more than the daylight hours of three consecutive days. 
(c)  Signs permitted. Notwithstanding any other provision of the City Code of Ordinances, one sign of not more than four square feet shall be permitted to be displayed on the property of the residence where a garage sale is being conducted pursuant to this article. In addition, no more than two directional signs may be placed in the city right-of-way; however, no such sign shall be displayed on the premises of the courthouse circle or any pedestrian islands therein. All signs shall be displayed only during daylight hours of the days of the sales. 
(d)  Enforcement; penalty. Any person found in violation of this section shall be given a written warning and notice to cease and desist. After such warning, and upon conviction, the violation shall be treated as a second degree misdemeanor and punishable by imprisonment of up to 60 days and a fine of $500.00. The chief of police or any police officer of the city may effect the arrest of a violator by warrant, or, if committed in the presence of such officer, without a warrant, as mandated in F.S. 901.15. 
(Ord. No. 2008-01, § 1, 1-8-2008) 
Sec. 58-14. - Operation of generators. 
(a)  Prohibited operation of a generator. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a generator for the purpose of producing electricity as a source of electrical power, except as provided herein. 
(b)  Permitted uses. Generators may be used to produce electricity in the case of emergency power outages caused by hurricanes, tornadoes, accidents, fallen trees, system failures and similar events, but only for the duration of such outage. Generators may also be operated to supply electricity for construction purposes, during daylight hours only, and for generator testing, maintenance and repair purposes. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person who violates this section shall be guilty of a second degree misdemeanor, punishable by fines or imprisonment as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2009-03, § 1, 10-6-2009) 
Sec. 58-15. - Operation of radios or other sound-making devices in motor vehicles. 
(a)  Prohibited noise. It shall be unlawful for any person operating or occupying a motor vehicle to amplify the sound produced by a radio, or a tape, CD or MP3 player, or other mechanical or electronic sound-making device or instrument from which the sound: 
(1)  Is plainly audible at a distance of 25 feet or more from the motor vehicle; 
or 
(2)  Is louder than necessary for the convenient hearing by persons inside the vehicle in areas adjoining churches, schools, hospitals, residences or businesses. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any law enforcement motor vehicle equipped with any communication device necessary in the performance of law enforcement duties or to any emergency vehicle equipped with any communication device necessary in the performance of any emergency procedures. 
(c)  The provisions of this section do not apply to the noise made by a horn or other warning device required or permitted by F.S. § 316.271. 
(d)  For the purpose of determining whether a violation of this section is occurring, law enforcement personnel shall use the following standards: 
(1)  "Plainly audible" shall mean any sound produced by a radio, tape player, or other mechanical or electronic sound-making device, or instrument, from within the interior or exterior of a motor vehicle, including sound produced by a portable sound-making device, that can be clearly heard outside the vehicle by a person using his normal hearing faculties, at a distance of 25 feet or more from the motor vehicle. 
(2)  Any law enforcement personnel who hear a sound that is plainly audible, as defined herein shall be entitled to measure the sound according to the following standards: 
a.  The primary means of detection shall be by means of the officer's ordinary auditory senses, so long as the officer's hearing is not enhanced by any mechanical device, such as a microphone or hearing aid. 
b.  The officer must have a direct line of sight and hearing, to the motor vehicle producing the sound so that he can readily identify the offending motor vehicle and the distance involved. 
c.  The officer need not determine the particular words or phrases being produced or the name of any song or artist producing the sound. The detection of rhythmic bass reverberating type sound is sufficient to constitute a plainly audible sound. 
(3)  The standards set forth in subsection (2) above shall also apply to the detection of sound that is louder than necessary for the convenient hearing of persons inside the motor vehicles in areas adjoining churches, schools, residences or businesses. 
(e)  Penalties. 
(1)  A person who violates a provision of this section is guilty of a civil infraction, which is punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(2)  Each occurrence of a violation constitutes a separate offense and may be punished separately. 
(f)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Issuance of citation. Sworn law enforcement officers of the City of Monticello are responsible for the enforcement of this section and shall function as "code enforcement officers," pursuant to F.S. ch. 162, for such purposes. Any law enforcement officer may issue a citation to a person to appear in county court when the officer, upon personal investigation, has reasonable cause to believe that the person has committed a civil infraction in violation of this section. 
(2)  Notice of violation. Because a violation of this section presents a serious threat to the pubic health, safety, or welfare of the residents of the City of Monticello, Florida, the law enforcement officer does not have to provide a reasonable time period to correct the violation prior to issuing a citation. 
(3)  Form of citation. The form of the citation shall contain the following: 
a.  The date and time issued. 
b.  The name and address of the person to whom the citation is issued. 
c.  The date and time the civil infraction was committed. 
d.  The facts constituting reasonable cause. 
e.  The number and section of the ordinance violated. 
f.  The name and authority of the law enforcement officer. 
g.  The procedure for the person to follow in order to pay the civil penalty or to contest the citation. 
h.  The applicable civil penalty if a person elects to contest the citation. 
i.  The applicable civil penalty if a person elects not to contest the citation. 
j.  A conspicuous statement that if a person fails to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed, or fails to appear in court to contest the citation, he or she shall be deemed to have waived his right to contest the citation and that, in such case, judgment may be entered against the person for an amount up to the maximum civil penalty. 
(4)  Filing a citation with county court. After issuing a citation to an alleged violator, a law enforcement officer shall deposit the original and one copy of the citation with the county court. Any person who willfully refuses to sign and accept a citation issued by a law enforcement officer shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree punishable as provided in F.S. §§ 775.082 or 775.083. 
(5)  Schedule of civil penalties. 
a.  A person who receives a citation from a law enforcement officer for a violation of this section and who elects not to contest the citation shall be subject to a civil penalty in accordance with the following schedule: 
1.  For a first offense, by a fine of $100.00, plus court costs. 
2.  For a second offense, by a fine of $250.00, plus court costs. 
3.  For third, and all subsequent offenses, by a fine of $350.00, plus court costs. 
b.  If a person who receives a citation elects to contest the citation, he or she must do so in county court. 
(6)  Judgment upon failure to contest citation. Any person who fails to pay the appropriate civil penalty with the time period allowed, or who fails to appear in county court to contest the citation, shall be deemed to have waived his or her right to contest the citation, and judgment may be entered against the person an amount not to exceed $500.00. 
(7)  Provisions supplemental. The provisions of this [article] are additional and supplemental means of enforcing this section. Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the city from enforcing this section by any other means. 
(Ord. No. 2013-04, § 1, 6-4-2013) 
Chapter 62 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Peddling at camp meeting, F.S. § 871.03. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hawker means all persons who shall sell or offer to sell at wholesale or retail any goods, wares or merchandise from a stand, wagon, motor vehicle, or push cart or upon any street or upon any public or vacant ground within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Peddler means all persons who are not hawkers who travel from place to place or from house to house selling or offering to sell any goods, wares or merchandise within the corporate limits of the city, except in the regular line of merchandising by actual bona fide merchants having a regular and fixed place of business within the city. 
    Retailer means any person who sells to the consumer. 
    Temporary premises means any hotel, roominghouse, storeroom, tent, trailer, motor or other vehicle, or building or any part of any building or structure of any kind, vacant lot, freight station, railroad car or any public or quasi-public place, temporarily occupied or used by a transient retail merchant. 
    Transient retail merchant means every person acting for himself/herself or representing any other person, who brings into temporary premises, in this city, any goods, wares, notions or articles of merchandise or trade of any character, and who solicits, sells or offers to sell or exhibits for sale, any such goods, wares, notions or articles of merchandise or trade, at retail or at auction. Such definition shall continue to apply until such person shall be continuously engaged in such business in the city for a period of one year. 
    Wholesaler means any person who sells to a retailer. 
(Code 1957, §§ 14-1(a)-(d), 14-9, 14-10; Code 1982, § 17-1) 
Sec. 62-2. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to scientific and literary lectures and entertainments, or to any regularly licensed auctioneer, or to any news dealer, or to a person using a motor vehicle owned by him/her, whether operated by him/her or his/her agent, for the transportation of produce produced by him/her on premises owned or rented by him/her when the entire course of such transportation extends not more than 70 miles from such premises; or to persons employed by any wholesale or retail business engaged in interstate commerce to solicit orders, on salary or commission. 
(Code 1957, § 14-6; Code 1982, § 17-2) 
Sec. 62-3. - Going in or upon private residences without invitation. 
(a)  Prohibited. The practice of going in and upon private residences in the city by solicitors, peddlers, hawkers, itinerant merchants or transient vendors of merchandise, not having been requested or invited so to do by the owner or owners, occupant or occupants of such private residences, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise and/or disposing of and/or peddling or hawking the same is declared to be a nuisance and punishable as such nuisance as for a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Exceptions. The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the sale or soliciting of orders for sale of milk, dairy products, vegetables, poultry, eggs and other farm and garden products so far as authorized by law. 
(Code 1957, § 14-2; Code 1982, §§ 17-3, 17-4) 
Sec. 62-4. - Refusal to leave premises. 
    No person conducting a business regulated by this chapter who enters upon premises owned, leased or rented by another shall refuse to leave such premises after having been notified by the owner or occupant of such premises, or his/her agent, to leave the same. 
(Code 1982, § 17-5) 
Sec. 62-5. - Business hours. 
    No hawker or peddler shall sell or offer to sell any article within the city at any time except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
(Code 1957, § 14-5; Code 1982, § 17-6) 
Sec. 62-6. - Obstructing traffic. 
    No peddler or hawker shall conduct his/her business in such a manner as to obstruct or interfere with the free use and passage of the streets, sidewalks and public ways. 
(Code 1957, § 14-5; Code 1982, § 17-7) 
Secs. 62-7-62-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 

Sec. 62-31. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business, trade or calling of a hawker or peddler within the corporate limits of the city without first having obtained a license to do so. 
(Code 1957, § 14-3; Code 1982, § 17-19) 
Sec. 62-32. - Application. 
    Each peddler or hawker, before conducting any business, as in this chapter defined, within the corporate limits of the city, shall make application to the city clerk for a license, specifying in the application his/her name and residence, the number of days or the period of time he/she will be engaged in the city in the conduct of such business, the article or articles to be sold or offered for sale and the manner of conducting the business. 
(Code 1957, § 14-4; Code 1982, § 17-20) 
Sec. 62-33. - Payment of fee by transient merchants. 
    Every transient retail merchant shall pay to the city clerk, in advance, as a license fee, the amount prescribed in chapter 26, article II, for each week or fraction thereof he/she conducts such business in the city. 
(Code 1957, § 14-11; Code 1982, § 17-21) 
Sec. 62-34. - Display. 
    Every person conducting a business regulated by this chapter and having a license issued hereunder shall display his/her license upon the request of any person. 
(Code 1982, § 17-22) 
Sec. 62-35. - Expiration; transfer. 
    All licenses issued under this article shall expire at the end of the tax year and shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1957, § 14-4; Code 1982, § 17-23) 
Chapter 66 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Community redevelopment, F.S. § 163.330 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AGENCY 

Sec. 66-31. - Created. 
    In conformity with and in furtherance of the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, a local planning agency is hereby created to establish and implement comprehensive planning programs to guide and control future development in the city. 
(Code 1982, § 19-16; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 1) 
State Law reference- Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq.; local planning agency, F.S. § 163.3174. 
Sec. 66-32. - Title. 
    The local planning agency shall be called the Monticello Planning Agency. 
(Code 1982, § 19-17; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 1) 
Sec. 66-33. - Composition. 
    The planning agency is to consist of five regular members, including, in addition, one ex officio nonvoting member of the city council and, in addition, one ex officio nonvoting member appointed by the school board, in accordance with F.S. § 163.3174. 
(Code 1982, § 19-18; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 2) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, F.S. § 163.3174. 
Sec. 66-34. - Appointment of regular members. 
    The regular members of the planning agency shall be selected and appointed by the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 19-19; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 4) 
Sec. 66-35. - Designation of ex officio member. 
    The member of the city council serving as an ex officio member of the planning agency shall be designated by the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 19-20; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 3) 
Sec. 66-36. - Officers. 
(a)  Generally. The planning agency shall select one of its regular members as chairperson, and one of its members, either regular or ex officio, as secretary. 
(b)  Interim chairperson. Should the chairperson of the planning agency be unable to attend a meeting, the members shall select an interim chairperson. 
(c)  Election. Only regular members of the planning agency shall be entitled to vote when selecting a full-time or interim chairperson, but all members shall be entitled to vote when selecting a secretary. 
(Code 1982, §§ 19-21-19-23; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 5) 
Sec. 66-37. - Funding; establishment of schedule of fees. 
(a)  The city shall provide funds for salaries, fees and expenses necessary in the conduct of the work of the planning agency and shall establish a schedule of fees to be charged by the agency. 
(b)  A resolution shall be adopted by the city council showing where the funds shall be appropriated by the city for the planning agency. 
(Code 1982, §§ 19-24, 19-25; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 15) 
State Law reference- Financial support for staffing and work of agency, F.S. § 163.3174. 
Sec. 66-38. - Acceptance of fees, gifts and loans. 
    The planning agency shall have the authority to accept fees, gifts, state or federal grants, state or federal loans and funds, etc., from other sources; provided, acceptance of loans must be approved by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 19-26; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 15) 
Sec. 66-39. - Financial statements. 
    The planning agency shall prepare monthly financial statements to the city of all expenditures made by the planning agency. 
(Code 1982, § 19-27; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 16) 
Sec. 66-40. - Meetings and records to be public. 
    All meetings of the planning agency shall be public, and all planning agency records shall be public records. 
(Code 1982, § 19-28; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 7) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, F.S. § 163.3174(5). 
Sec. 66-41. - Time and place of regular meetings. 
    The planning agency shall meet on the second Wednesday of each month at 7:30 p.m. in the city hall or such other time as may be scheduled by the city council on proper notice. 
(Code 1982, § 19-29; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 6) 
Sec. 66-42. - Rules of order. 
    All meetings of the planning agency shall be governed procedurally by Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised unless other rules are adopted by the planning agency. 
(Code 1982, § 19-30; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 13) 
Sec. 66-43. - Authority of ex officio members. 
    Ex officio members of the planning agency shall have no voting privileges and shall have no right to present motions before it, but shall have the opportunity to participate in discussion and evaluation of proposals, and arguments in favor of and in opposition thereto. 
(Code 1982, § 19-31; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 3) 
Sec. 66-44. - Public participation in planning process. 
(a)  Implementation. The city council and the planning agency are charged with establishing public participation in the planning process. 
(b)  Methods. Public participation in the planning process shall be encouraged by the following methods, but not limited thereto: 
(1)  Advance notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the area where any meeting of the planning agency will be held. 
(2)  A regular member of the planning agency shall be appointed as a public relations representative, who is responsible for giving information to all other news media. Said member shall assist the planning agency as required of the agency under section 8 of the Local Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq. 
(Code 1982, §§ 19-32, 19-33; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 14) 
State Law reference- Public participation in the comprehensive planning process, F.S. § 163.3181. 
Sec. 66-45. - Hearings. 
    The planning agency shall have the authority to hold public hearings. 
(Code 1982, § 19-34; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 11) 
Sec. 66-46. - Conduct of comprehensive planning program; preparation of comprehensive plan. 
    The city assigns to the planning agency the general responsibility for the conduct of the comprehensive planning program and the preparation of the comprehensive plan, or elements or portions thereof, as defined and outlined in the Local Government Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, F.S. § 163.3161 et seq. 
(Code 1982, § 19-35; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 8) 
State Law reference- Preparation of comprehensive plan, F.S. § 163.3174. 
Sec. 66-47. - Comprehensive plan to be based on appropriate data. 
    It is the responsibility of the planning agency to base the comprehensive plan upon data appropriate to the element involved. 
(Code 1982, § 19-36; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 19) 
State Law reference- Required and optional elements of comprehensive plan, F.S. § 163.3177. 
Sec. 66-48. - Responsibility for recommending adoption of comprehensive plan. 
    The city council, in cooperation with the planning agency, may designate any agency, committee, department or person to prepare the comprehensive plan or any element thereof, but the responsibility for final recommendation of the adoption of such plan to the city council shall be the responsibility of the planning agency. 
(Code 1982, § 19-37; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 9) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 163.3174. 
Sec. 66-49. - Monitoring of comprehensive plan; recommendation of changes to plan. 
    The planning agency shall monitor and oversee the effectiveness and status of the comprehensive plan and recommend to the city council such changes in the comprehensive plan as may from time to time be required. 
(Code 1982, § 19-38; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, F.S. § 163.3174. 
Sec. 66-50. - Review of zoning provisions. 
    The planning agency shall initiate a review of the provisions of zoning regulations and ordinances. 
(Code 1982, § 19-39; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 12) 
Sec. 66-51. - Attendance at meetings; removal of members. 
    Any regular member or ex officio member of the planning agency who fails to attend two consecutive meetings may be removed by the city council. No regular member or ex officio member shall be removed unless for good cause or as provided in this section. 
(Code 1982, § 19-40; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 17) 
Sec. 66-52. - Vacancies. 
    Any vacancy in the office of a regular member, or the council member serving as an ex officio member, of the planning agency may be filled by the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 19-41; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 4) 
Sec. 66-53. - Term of regular members. 
    Regular members shall serve on the planning agency for three years. 
(Code 1982, § 19-42; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 4) 
Sec. 66-54. - Term of ex officio member. 
    The term of an ex officio member of the planning agency from the city council shall be two years. 
(Code 1982, § 19-43; Ord. of 7-6-1976, § 3) 
Secs. 66-55-66-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LANDSCAPING OF OFF-STREET PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 66-81. - Violations; penalties; injunctive relief. 
    Violation of the provisions of this article shall be punishable as a misdemeanor of the second degree. Alternatively, the city may enforce compliance with this article by injunctive relief in the circuit court of the county, in which event attorney's fees and costs shall be assessed against the person or corporation found to be in violation of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 19-55; Ord. of 2-7-1978, § VII) 
Sec. 66-82. - Objectives. 
    The objective of this article is to establish requirements for the installation and maintenance of landscape elements in off-street parking areas. The justification for such an article is three-fold: 
(1)  To aid in regulating and controlling vehicular and pedestrian circulation; 
(2)  To enhance the community's ecological or environmental and aesthetic qualities; and 
(3)  To protect and conserve the value of property. 
(Code 1982, § 19-56; Ord. of 2-7-1978, § I) 
Sec. 66-83. - Applicability. 
    The requirements and standards for the installation and maintenance of landscape elements and site improvements as set forth herein shall apply to all off-street parking areas within the city having more than six parking spaces. 
(Code 1982, § 19-57; Ord. of 2-7-1978, § II) 
Sec. 66-84. - Maintenance. 
    The owner shall be responsible for the maintenance of all landscape areas which shall be maintained so as to present a healthy, neat and orderly appearance at all times and shall be kept free from refuse and debris. 
(Code 1982, § 19-58; Ord. of 2-7-1978, § II) 
Sec. 66-85. - Use of artificial plant materials. 
    Synthetic or artificial material in the form of trees, shrubs, ground covers or vines shall not be used in lieu of plant requirements in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 19-59; Ord. of 2-7-1978, § II) 
Sec. 66-86. - Required interior landscaping. 
    Interior landscape development for off-street parking areas shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  A minimum of five percent of the total developed area, less building area, of any parcel of property which comes within the provisions of this article shall be devoted to landscape development. 
(2)  Trees shall be placed within interior planting areas such that the total number of trees provided in the interior planting areas, along the perimeter, and adjacent to public rights-of-way shall be equal to one tree for every 5,000 square feet of paved area. 
(Code 1982, § 19-60; Ord. of 2-7-1978, § III) 
Sec. 66-87. - Plan approval. 
(a)  Appropriate plans showing proposed landscape development shall be submitted to the city council for site plan approval where such approval is required in chapter 54 (the land development regulations). 
(b)  Provided, however, that no plan shall be approved as submitted until it is determined by the building inspector that such plans have been prepared by a licensed landscape architect in accordance with F.S. § 481.303(6). Any plan rejected for failure to comply with the above statute may be resubmitted at such time as the landscape elements are prepared and submitted by a licensed landscape architect. 
(Code 1982, § 19-61; Ord. of 2-7-1978, § IV; Ord. No. 89-08, §§ 1, 2, 11-7-1989) 
Sec. 66-88. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The application and enforcement of this article shall be construed as an exercise of the police power to regulate, control and restrict the use of buildings, structures and land. 
(b)  The building inspector shall enforce the provisions of this article and require adherence to the requirements of installation and maintenance of landscape material herein specified. 
(Code 1982, § 19-62; Ord. of 2-7-1978, § V) 
Secs. 66-89-66-110. - Reserved.

Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, adopted June 3, 2010, amended Ch. 70 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 70, §§ 70-1-70-7, 70-31-70-37, 70-61-70-66, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1957; Ord. of 7-2-1974; Ord. of 2-6-1979; Ord. of 3-4-1980; Ord. of 11-18-1980; Code 1982; Ord. of 12-7-1982; Ord. No. 92-08, 9-1-1992; Ord. No. 2000-08, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 2000-10, 11-7-2000; Ord. No. 2003-08, 10-7-2003. 
State Law reference- Florida Resource Recovery and Management Act, F.S. § 403.702 et seq.; municipal public works, F.S. ch. 180. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Users of municipal collection and disposal system. 
    All persons owning or occupying, as owner, tenant or otherwise, any residence, apartment or place of business, residential or commercial, inhabited or used within the city shall be entitled to the removal by the city of garbage and trash from such premises. They shall be and are hereby declared and required to be a user of the garbage collection and disposal system and shall pay such fees, rates and charges therefore as are hereby established, or as are hereafter modified or changed by the city council. All charges that remain unpaid for a period of ten days after they shall become due and payable shall constitute a lien against the property from which the garbage and/or trash is collected to enforce payment of delinquent charges. Such delinquent sums may be recovered by the city as provided by law or by the discontinuance of the public utility service herein established until delinquent charges for service are paid. The city shall have the right to discontinue public utility water service unless garbage collection and disposal charges are paid. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-2. - Records of municipal collection system; duties of city clerk. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep an accurate record of all persons using the services and facilities of the municipal garbage collection and disposal system of the city, and to make charges in accordance with the rates and charges established in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-3. - Collection of hazardous waste prohibited. 
    The collection and disposal of special solid waste, including hazardous waste, biohazardous waste and construction waste shall be the sole responsibility of the owner or occupant of the property upon which the waste is generated or located. Any collection and disposal of such waste shall be in strict compliance with all federal, state and local laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-4. - Residential receptacles required; standards. 
(a)  Receptacles required. Each single-family residence within the corporate limits of the city shall provide at least one garbage can or receptacle of the specifications provided in this section, and each multiple-family residence or apartment building shall be equipped with one garbage can or receptacle for each family residing in such residence or apartment building, which garbage can or receptacle shall be of the specifications provided in this section. Each store, hotel, restaurant or other place of business located within the corporate limits of the city shall be equipped with such garbage can or receptacle as may from time to time be specified by the city. 
(b)  Capacity; materials; cover. Each garbage can or receptacle shall have a capacity of not less than ten gallons and not more than 40 gallons, be of metal or plastic, free from holes or leaks and shall be provided with an appropriate cover sufficient to prevent the entrance of rain water and insects. 
(c)  Cans to be kept covered; location. Each garbage can or receptacle shall be kept securely covered at all times except when being filled or emptied, and shall be located at such place on the premises as will make it easily accessible to the collectors. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-5. - Emptying of receptacles and disposal of contents. 
(a)  Residences. Each garbage can or receptacle located at any place of residence shall be emptied at least twice each week and the contents thereof disposed of as directed by the city. 
(b)  Business establishments. Each garbage can or receptacle located at a place of business shall be emptied and the contents disposed of as may from time to time be required by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-6. - Cleaning of weeds and refuse from lots. 
(a)  Duty of owner; applicability. It is declared to be the duty and responsibility of the owner of each and every lot, piece and parcel of land located within the city to keep each such lot, piece or parcel of land as lies within 500 feet of any residence, mercantile or other business building, church building or school building reasonably free and clear of weeds, grass, garbage, waste and trash therefrom as often as may be reasonably necessary; provided, however, that the requirements of this section shall not apply to swamp and overflowed lands. 
(b)  Cleaning by city authorized. Where any owner of any lot, piece or parcel of land as is referred to in subsection (a) of this section has failed to keep such lot, piece or parcel of land reasonably free and clean from weeds, grass, garbage, waste and trash, it shall be the duty of the city to cause the weeds and grass on any such lot, piece or parcel of land to be cut and the garbage, waste and trash to be removed therefrom at the expense of the owner thereof. 
(c)  Procedure for notification. Upon determination by the city manager that any parcel, lot or portion thereof referred to in subsection (a) of this section is overgrown with weeds or trash, the city clerk shall give 15 days notice in writing demanding the owner, in care of the person in whose name the real property taxes are billed, to immediately improve such property by cutting, burning or hauling away such trash and mowing weeds or undergrowth from said property. Upon certification by the city manager to the city clerk of noncompliance, the city council shall have the authority to determine and declare the existence of a public nuisance as outlined in Chapter 38 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-7. - Depositing shrubbery trimmings on street, sidewalk or gutter. 
    It shall be unlawful under any pretense whatever for any person to deposit any trash or trimmings of shrubbery on any of the sidewalks or water gutters or streets of the city unless permission is obtained to do so from the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-8. - Burning or burying garbage. 
    No garbage, trash or yard waste shall be burned or buried within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-9. - Littering. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, sweep, place or deposit any garbage, trash, rubbish, weeds or filth of any kind on any sidewalk, street or alley or upon any vacant lot or into or upon the premises of any other person or into any waters or upon the banks thereof within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-10. - Placement and screening of refuse and recycling mechanical, dumpster, compaction, and roll-off containers. 
(a)  Screening required. All permanently located refuse or recycling mechanical, dumpster, compaction, or roll-off containers in use within the city limits shall be screened from view of any public right-of-way by September 1, 2010, as follows: 
(1)  Screening shall be on at least three sides and shall consist of wood, vinyl-coated chain-link fence with slats, brick, stone, concrete or similar material approved by the city manager. Screening shall encompass the full height, length, and width of the container, and each enclosure shall provide a minimum of 24 inches of clear space between each side of the dumpster, including lifting flanges and the adjacent wall surface of that enclosure or any other dumpsters within that same enclosure. All screening structures shall be reasonably accessible for collection service vehicles and shall not be located within the right-of-way of any public street or alleyway. All screenings shall be maintained for function, safety, and appearance. Newly-constructed screening enclosures located within the Historic District of the City of Monticello must be subject to the standard procedures for review and approval of new construction within the historic district as outlined in Chapter 54, Article VII. 
(2)  Gates intended for service access shall provide an opening width of at least ten feet for each mechanical container and shall be designed to remain open during collection service. Gates shall be required when the service entrance of the screening enclosure faces a public right-of-way, or is visible from a residential zoning district. Gates that swing out from the container shall be set back from the property line at least a distance equal to the width of the gate. Gate hinge assemblies shall be strong and durable so that access and servicing gates function properly and do not sag. 
(3)  Where a gate in the screening structure faces a public right-of-way, or is visible from a residential district, the gate shall be closed except when collection service is provided. The service provider may close any gate left open in violation of this subsection. A service fee of $5.00 for each such closure service provided by the service provider shall be assessed against the owner or occupant of the property and shall be supplemental to any other penalties provided for and collected in the manner provided by section 70-66. 
(4)  All screening enclosures applicable under this section shall be placed on poured concrete, solid or perforated interlocking concrete block paving, or any existing hardened paving system. 
(b)  Waiver of location requirements. When existing site conditions do not lend themselves to a location that conforms with the requirements of this section, the city manager is authorized to grant waivers from the required number of required parking spaces, minimum pervious area requirements, or landscaping, buffering, and/or setback requirements of the Land Development Code in order to accommodate the location of an existing refuse or recycling mechanical, dumpster, compaction, or roll-off container in conformance with this section. In considering which, if any, waivers to grant, the city manager shall consider the number, extent and relative importance of existing and resulting non-conformities to proper site functioning and compatibility with adjacent uses. 
(c)  Waiver of screening requirements. The city manager may grant exceptions to the container screening enclosure requirements of this section, and allow the container service to remain, where specific lot conditions make compliance impractical, the visibility of the container from a roadway is minimal, or the safety of the collection vehicle or the public in general would be compromised by the construction of the screening enclosure. 
(d)  Temporary mechanical, dumpster, compaction or roll-off containers used for the collection of refuse or recycling during special events for a period of less than seven days are exempt from the container screening requirements contained in this section. 
(e)  Refuse or recycling mechanical or dumpster containers on wheels which are stored out of the public view, except during collections, are exempt from the screening requirement of this section. 
(f)  Temporary mechanical, dumpster, compaction or roll-off containers used for the collection of refuse or recycling during construction activities are exempt from the container screening requirements contained in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Secs. 70-11-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 70-31. - Title. 
    This article shall be entitled "Commercial Establishments-Garbage and Refuse Regulations." 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-32. - Definition. 
    For purposes of this article, a commercial establishment is defined as any individual, firm, partnership or corporation that owns, operates, leases or otherwise occupies a business establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-33. - Disposal of wet garbage. 
    No commercial establishment shall dispose of "wet" garbage, including vegetables, poultry, meats, fish or fruit, unless prior to said disposal and placement in garbage receptacles, such garbage is specially placed in a separate container, either plastic bag-type or other leakproof, sealable container, so as to effectively seal and prevent said garbage from emitting odors or leaking fluids or other materials into any common garbage receptacle. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-34. - Disposal of crates, boxes or shipping containers. 
    All commercial establishments shall not dispose of any crates, boxes, cartons or shipping containers of any kind in any city container, receptacle or dumpster without first breaking up same in sections or pieces no larger in measurement than two feet by two feet by three inches, approximately. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Secs. 70-35-70-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RATES 

Sec. 70-61. - Applicability. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use the city garbage disposal or dumping area without paying the tax, rate or charges levied in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-62. - Residential rates. 
    There is hereby established the following minimum uniform schedule of rates and charges for garbage collection and disposal services: 
(1)  For each single-family or duplex dwelling unit inside the limits of the city, the sum of $15.00 per unit per month. 
(2)  For each single-family or duplex dwelling unit outside the limits of the city, the sum of $18.75 per unit per month. 
(3)  For each apartment unit as part of an apartment complex inside the city which is served by common garbage dumpsters, the sum of $14.50 per month. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010; Ord. No. 2013-09, § 1, 9-3-2013; Ord. No. 2018-03, § 1, 1-9-2018) 
Sec. 70-63. - Base rates for commercial establishments. 
    The rate categories and monthly base rates for city garbage collection services for commercial establishments is as follows:

(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-64. - Determination of rates for special circumstances. 
    If, in the judgment of the city manager special circumstances render the established rates for commercial garbage collection inequitable, he may authorize special rates as the circumstances dictate. Persons aggrieved by such a decision of the city manager made hereunder have the right to appeal to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-65. - Exclusions from regular garbage collection; special charges. 
(a)  Exclusions for regular garbage collection. Excluded from regular garbage collection shall be tires, appliances, mattresses, furniture, metal, construction debris, or other items which, either whole or disassembled, will not fit into a 40-gallon garbage can. Pickup by city crews of these items shall be by special charge, based on size and weight, set by the city manager, payable in advance. 
(b)  Vegetative yard waste. The basic fee for residential garbage collection and disposal service shall include a reasonable amount up to four clamp buckets full per month of small vegetative yard waste and/or tree stumps and logs measuring less than 24 inches long and ten inches in diameter. The charge for removal of felled trees, stumps and logs greater than a diameter of ten inches or the pickup of excessive (more than four clamp buckets full) of additional yard waste shall be at the following pre-paid special rate: 
One-quarter truck load ..... $50.00 
One-half truck load ..... $100.00 
Three-quarter truck load ..... $150.00 
Full truck load ..... $200.00 
    Vegetative waste must be separated from other trash and debris. Rolloff containers should be used when possible. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 70-66. - Billing; failure to pay charges; discontinuance of water service. 
    The rates and charges set forth in this article shall be added to and included in the regular monthly bills or statements rendered to the consumers of water and/or sewer of the city. Persons using the services and facilities of the municipal garbage collection and disposal system who are not consumers of water shall be rendered monthly bills or statements for the use of the services and facilities of said system, which said bills or statements shall be rendered and shall be payable at the same time and in the same manner and subject to the same penalties and discontinuance of service of said system as in the case of a failure of a consumer of water of the city to pay the rates and charges imposed under the terms of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-06, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Chapter 74 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Local municipal improvements, F.S. ch. 170; gas tax used for street construction, F.S. § 206.625; minimum standards for streets, sidewalks, etc., F.S. § 336.045; municipal public works, F.S. ch. 180. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Authority of council to order laying of sidewalks. 
    The city council shall have the power to order the laying of sidewalks along all public streets of the city, and to prescribe the width thereof, and the material to be used in their construction, after 30 days' notice to the abutting property owner, and upon failure of such property owner within such time to lay any such sidewalk so ordered, shall have the power to cause such sidewalk to be laid, and to assess the cost and expense of the same against such abutting property, which shall be and become a lien on any such abutting property, and may be enforced as other liens in a court of equity. 
(Laws of Fla. ch. 9026(1921), § 22) 
Sec. 74-2. - Obstructions and encroachments on streets, sidewalks and public rights-of-way. 
(a)  Obstructions and encroachments. It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation or other entity to close, obstruct or encroach upon, under any pretense, any of the squares, streets, sidewalks or public rights-of-way within the city, except for those permitted temporary use(s) authorized in this section. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed so as to prevent merchants from receiving and delivering their goods and wares, or prevent the erection of scaffolds and ladders or storing materials for the purpose of building and repairing, provided a valid building permit has been issued. 
(b)  Permitted temporary uses. Sidewalk retail displays and restaurant tables and seating in B-1 business district: retail merchandise and decorative displays and restaurant seating on the public sidewalks of the City of Monticello are authorized only in the downtown B-1 business zoning district. Such activities are limited to commercial establishments, including restaurants, in buildings abutting public sidewalks and only directly in front of the buildings where the business is located, and only when the owner or lessee of such commercial establishment is the holder of a valid temporary use permit issued by the city. 
(1)  Temporary use permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation or other entity to install or place any merchandise for display or sale, decorative displays, or restaurant tables and seating, on any sidewalk within the city, without a temporary use permit issued as provided in this section. Such permit shall be a license by the city to use the sidewalk, and shall not grant, nor shall it be construed or considered to grant, any person, corporation, and/or other entity any property right or interest in the public sidewalk, nor shall it be construed to constitute a vacation or abandonment of such public sidewalk by the city, or any other governmental entity owning a sidewalk within the city. 
a.  Applications for temporary use permits. An application for a temporary use permit shall be on a form provided by the city, and shall be accompanied by a site plan, a current city business tax receipt, an application fee established by the city, an indemnification and hold harmless agreement, and evidence of liability insurance in an amount determined by the city. 
1.  The site plan must include a narrative describing of the size or dimension, the style, type, materials and construction of the proposed retail displays or the proposed restaurant tables and seating, a diagram of the layout or positioning of the proposed retail displays or restaurant tables and seating, and showing the American with Disabilities Act ("ADA") required accessibility areas. The ADA accessibility areas must remain clear of all merchandise, retail displays or restaurant tables and seating at all times. 
2.  The indemnification and hold harmless agreement shall be on a form provided by the city, and shall provide that the holder of the temporary use permit agrees to indemnify, defend, save and hold harmless the city and any other governmental entity owning public sidewalks in the B-1 business zoning district, their officers, agents and employees, from any and all claims, demands, liability, lawsuits, damages and all causes of action arising from, or as a result of, the permit holder's placement of anything on the public sidewalk. 
3.  The application fee will be due at the time of submission of an application for any temporary use permit under this section. The fee will be established by resolution of the city council. 
(2)  Duration of temporary use permits. A temporary use permit may be issued by the city for a period of up to 12 months, after the permit application and site plan have been approved by the city manager, the execution of the hold harmless agreement and payment of the permit fee. 
(c)  Standards for permitted retail displays and restaurant tables and seating. The city shall set standards for retail merchandise displays, restaurant seating, other items permitted for use on sidewalks and public rights-of-way: 
(1)  Retail merchandise displays. Merchandise and/or decorative displays may be placed on the city sidewalk parallel to the abutting building front entrance in an area measuring no more than 60 percent of the building sidewalk frontage directly abutting the building, and only on the frontage containing the main entrance to the business. Such displays shall allow an efficient, direct and unimpeded pedestrian path along the sidewalk that is directly parallel to the display area and directly into the building front entrance. The pedestrian path must be at least 42 inches wide, or meet minimum ADA requirements, whichever is greater. No display may be less than 24 inches tall or exceed five feet in height. Placement of the display must adhere to the requirements of the ADA and all other applicable standards and not obstruct the storefront entrance or corner sight visibility. Only merchandise and goods offered for sale within a store may be displayed in front of the exterior storefront. Such merchandise and goods may be located on sturdy support structures and shall be maintained in a safe and clean manner. Merchandise and support structures shall be removed from the right-of-way or secured when the business is closed. Advertising signage in outdoor display areas must be displayed in a secure manner and shall not exceed four square feet. 
(2)  Benches, tables, seats and floral decorations. Benches, tables and seats may be provided, from time to time, by the city on and along the sidewalks in appropriate areas and, if provided, will be available for the general public's use. Businesses in buildings abutting the sidewalks may place approved benches against the abutting wall in front of the business, and may place floral decorations and flower containers on the sidewalk in front of the business. Such permitted benches, floral decorations and flower containers may not interfere with ADA access requirements for the sidewalk or for the main entrance to the restaurant or business. Benches may not have any signage or advertising. Any permitted items placed on the sidewalk in this section must be properly maintained and not permitted to become an eyesore. 
(3)  Restaurant tables and seating. Restaurant tables and seating approved in the application may be placed on sidewalks within the city, parallel to and abutting the building owned or leased by the permit holder where the restaurant is located in, an area measuring not more than 80 percent of the buildings sidewalk frontage. All restaurant tables, seating and other objects shall allow an efficient, direct and unimpeded pedestrian path along the sidewalk that is directly parallel to the sidewalk restaurant seating area and directly into the restaurant main entrance. The pedestrian path must be at least 42 inches wide, or meet minimum ADA requirements, whichever is greater. Restaurant tables and seating must is limited to those described in the permit application, and shall be limited to the number and areas depicted on the applicant's approved site plan. Placement of all restaurant seating must adhere to the requirements of the ADA, and all other applicable standards in statutes, ordinances and rules, and must not obstruct the building entrance or corner site visibility. Restaurant tables and seating must be of an appropriate style or design, similar to cafe/bistro tables and chairs, as approved by the city manager or as designated, from time to time, by the city council. 
(4)  Advertising. No advertising or other signage is allowed to be affixed to any city-owned benches or seats on a sidewalk or in the public right-of-way. 
(5)  Removal. The city and/or other public agency owning the right-of-way may require the removal of outdoor merchandise, decorative displays and outdoor restaurant seating from the public right-of-ways during street, sidewalk or utility repairs, during emergency situations, or when heavy pedestrian traffic is expected due to a permitted festival or parade. 
(d)  Enforcement. If a city code enforcement officer determines that any decorative display, merchandise, goods or restaurant tables and seating, benches or floral decorations is/are in a state of disrepair, unclean, unsafe, unsightly or not in compliance with the permit site plan or with the standards contained in this section, or if such code enforcement agent has determined that the holder of the permit or owner of the real estate for which the permit is issued is in violation of any other municipal ordinance or regulation or state statute, the code enforcement officer shall give written notice to the permit holder of the unsatisfactory condition of the facility and/or violation. Thereafter, the provisions of this section shall be enforced pursuant to section 1-13 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1957, § 16-4; Code 1982, § 23-1; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 2, 10-4-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-01, § 2, adopted Oct. 4, 2016, changed the title of § 74-2 from "Obstructions and encroachments on streets" to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference- Obstructing highway, F.S. §§ 861.01, 861.011. 
Sec. 74-3. - Spitting on sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to spit upon any of the sidewalks within the city. 
(Code 1957, § 13-37; Code 1982, § 23-8) 
Secs. 74-4-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 74-31. - Permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any construction or repair work involving the tearing up and re-laying of any street or any part of a street or to obstruct, dig up or into or in any way disturb any street or any part of a street, including removal of earth from ditches, in the city without first procuring from the city council a written permit therefor. The permit provided for in this section shall be issued under such conditions as may be prescribed by the city council, shall accurately describe the portion of the street to be affected, shall make provision for the replacement of that part of the street which is to be replaced in the same condition as when disturbed, and shall state a definite time within which the permit shall be operative. 
(Code 1957, § 16-1; Code 1982, § 23-5) 
Sec. 74-32. - Barricades and lights. 
    Any person carrying on or doing any construction, excavation or repair work in any street or any part of a street in the city pursuant to a permit from the city council, as provided in section 74-31, shall erect and maintain proper, safe and sufficient barricades, and during that period of time between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise shall maintain sufficient lights or flares around such barricades, work or excavations to warn persons of the presence of such excavations and work and to prevent injury to persons and property. 
(Code 1957, § 16-2; Code 1982, § 23-6) 
Sec. 74-33. - Replacement of street. 
    Upon the expiration of any permit granted by the city council pursuant to the provisions of section 74-31, the permit holder shall replace that street or that part of a street upon which such construction, excavation or repair work has been performed in the same condition as the street or part of street existed prior to the construction, excavation or repair work. 
(Code 1957, § 16-3; Code 1982, § 23-7) 
Chapter 78 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Taxation, F.S. ch. 192 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 78-1-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INSURANCE 

Sec. 78-31. - Tax on property insurance premiums. 
(a)  Levied.
