    Written permission for all parades or processions, either of pedestrians or of motor vehicles, must be obtained from the mayor (except for such as are sponsored by or involve the military forces of the state or of the United States of America), who shall designate the day, time and the route of such parade or procession. 
(Code 1957, § 18-31; Code 1982, § 14-62) 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate processions or assemblages on streets, F.S. § 316.008(1)(c). 
Sec. 86-63. - Issuance of permit. 
    The mayor, when satisfied that a parade or procession is for lawful purposes and that the holding thereof at the time and along routes requested will not unnecessarily endanger human life or property or unreasonably obstruct or interfere with the efficient and orderly flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, whether such traffic is along the streets or sidewalks of the city or from such streets or sidewalks into public or private property, shall issue a written permit for such parade or procession, stating thereon the day and time for which such permit is valid, the route approved and designated for such parade or procession and any other necessary or desirable information. A written copy of such permit will be furnished to the chief of police, who, under the supervision of the mayor, shall be responsible that this division is fairly and strictly enforced. 
(Code 1957, § 18-31; Code 1982, § 14-63) 
Sec. 86-64. - Driving in procession. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1957, § 18-34; Code 1982, § 14-64) 
Sec. 86-65. - Unlawful assemblages. 
    All demonstrations, public addresses, public meetings or congregating of persons upon the streets or sidewalks of the city or upon public property within the city which tend to obstruct or disrupt the lawful, orderly and efficient flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, whether such traffic is along the streets or sidewalks of the city or from such streets or sidewalks into public or private property, and similar activities wherein persons acting jointly or in concert and by noisy disturbances, boisterous conduct or obscene or loud, or threatening language or gestures while obstructing the streets or sidewalks of the city to lawful and orderly traffic thereon, are hereby declared unlawful; persons participating therein shall be guilty of an offense under this Code, and such activities are hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1957, § 18-31; Code 1982, § 14-65) 
State Law reference- Abatement of nuisance by injunction, F.S. §§ 60.05, 60.06. 
Secs. 86-66-86-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic control devices, F.S. § 316.074 et seq.; power of city to regulate traffic by means of official traffic control devices, F.S. § 316.008(1)(b). 

Sec. 86-101. - Effect of traffic control devices. 
    The existence of signs, signals and markings, duly installed by the chief of police or under his/her authority, shall be sufficient proof of the existence of the regulations made under this chapter by the chief of police. 
(Code 1957, § 18-2; Code 1982, § 14-26) 
Sec. 86-102. - Obedience to no-turn signs and turning markers. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left or U-turns are permitted, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of any such sign, and when authorized marks, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be traveled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Code 1957, § 18-56; Code 1982, § 14-27) 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate or prohibit the turning of vehicles, F.S. § 316.008(1)(i). 
Sec. 86-103. - One-way streets. 
    Vehicular traffic shall move only in the indicated direction when signs indicating the direction of traffic are erected and maintained at every intersection where movement in the opposite direction is prohibited. 
(Code 1957, § 18-52; Code 1982, § 14-28) 
State Law reference- Power of city to designate one-way streets, F.S. § 316.008(1)(d). 
Secs. 86-104-86-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, F.S. § 316.194 et seq. 

Sec. 86-141. - Parking for purpose of sale or repair of vehicle. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying it for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing the vehicle except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Code 1957, § 18-61; Code 1982, § 14-76) 
State Law reference- Power of city to restrict use of streets, F.S. § 316.008(1)(g). 
Sec. 86-142. - Parking with left side of vehicle to curb. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, with the left side of the vehicle to the curb. 
(Code 1957, § 18-62; Code 1982, § 14-77) 
Sec. 86-143. - Angle parking. 
    Upon those streets which have been marked or signed for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such mark or sign. 
(Code 1957, § 18-60; Code 1982, § 14-78) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, F.S. § 316.195. 
Sec. 86-144. - Manner of parking in loading zones. 
    In places where and at hours when stopping for the loading or unloading of merchandise or materials is permitted, vehicles used for the transportation of merchandise or materials may back into the curb to take on or discharge loads when the owner of such vehicle holds a permit granting him/her such privilege, and such permit shall be either in the possession of the driver or on the vehicle at the time such vehicle is backed against the curb to take on or discharge a load. It shall be unlawful for any owner or driver to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such special permit. 
(Code 1957, § 18-60; Code 1982, § 14-79) 
State Law reference- Authority for special permits, F.S. § 316.550. 
Sec. 86-145. - Use of loading zones. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to loading zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(Code 1957, § 18-64; Code 1982, § 14-80) 
Sec. 86-146. - Use of passenger zones. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger zone during the hours when the regulations applicable to such passenger zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes. 
(Code 1957, § 18-64; Code 1982, § 14-81) 
Sec. 86-147. - Moving car from parked position. 
    Cars parked shall move out in the direction headed, or if they are parked at an angle with the curb they shall back out on that angle until they have cleared the other cars and shall proceed in the direction in which they are most nearly headed. 
(Code 1957, § 18-68; Code 1982, § 14-82) 
Sec. 86-148. - Impoundment of illegally parked vehicles. 
    The chief of police or any police officer of the city is hereby authorized to take up or cause to be taken up or removed to a place designated by the mayor, any vehicle parked in violation of any of the provisions of the parking ordinances, and is authorized and empowered to keep same in such place so designated by the mayor until all fines and charges assessed for moving and storage against the owner and the car have been paid or satisfactory bond arranged. 
(Code 1957, § 18-69; Code 1982, § 14-83) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate or prohibit parking, F.S. § 316.008. 
Sec. 86-149. - Violation tickets. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the police officers of the city, acting in accordance with the instructions issued by the city council, to deposit with the city clerk the stub of every violation ticket. Such stub shall contain: 
(1)  The number of the parking meter adjacent to the vehicle which was parked in violation of this article. 
(2)  The state license number of such vehicle. 
(3)  The day and hour at which such vehicle is parked in violation of the article. 
(4)  Any other facts which the officer deems necessary to properly understand the circumstances of the violation. 
(b)  Every such police officer shall also place on such vehicle a notice to the owner thereof that such vehicle has been parked in violation of the provisions of this article and instructing such owner to report to such authority as may be designated by law in regard to such violation. 
(Code 1957, § 18-84; Code 1982, § 14-84) 
State Law reference- Judicial power of state, Fla. Const. art. V. 
Sec. 86-150. - Improper parking; overtime parking. 
    No owner or operator of any vehicle shall cause, allow, permit or suffer such vehicle to be parked overtime or beyond the period of the legal parking time nor may he/she cause, allow, permit or suffer such vehicle to be parked in any manner contrary to the manner prescribed by this article. 
(Code 1957, § 18-79; Code 1982, § 14-85) 
Sec. 86-151. - Parking on courthouse circle. 
(a)  There shall be a limit of one hour for all vehicle parking, on all days except Sunday, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. through 7:00 p.m. in the following described area: the northeast quadrant of the courthouse circle running easterly from North Jefferson Street to the north boundary of U.S. Highway 19. 
(b)  This area shall be considered a restricted parking area, and no motor vehicle, truck, motorcycle, or any motorized conveyance of any kind shall be permitted to park in the described area in excess of one continuous hour each day. All violations of this section shall be punished by a fine of $5.00 imposed and collected by the police department and payable to the city. 
(c)  Appropriate visible signs shall be placed in the above-described area with a generalized notice of the one-hour parking limitation. 
(d)  There is excepted from the provisions of this section any law enforcement vehicle on official business at the county courthouse either transporting or delivering prisoners or engaged in other official law enforcement duties. 
(Ord. No. 93-01, §§ 1-4, 1-5-1993) 
Sec. 86-152. - Parking meters. 
    The city council may from time to time designate locations for the installation of parking meters where such meters will best serve the citizens of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 14-86) 
Sec. 86-153. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
    The duties of enforcing the provisions of this article shall be upon the mayor, acting through the chief of police and the police department. 
(Code 1957, § 18-83; Code 1982, § 14-87) 
Secs. 86-154-86-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BICYCLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Bicycle regulations, F.S. § 316.2065 et seq. 

Sec. 86-181. - Applicability. 
    The regulations applicable to bicycles in this article shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any street or sidewalk or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, subject to those exceptions stated herein. 
(Code 1957, § 5-2; Code 1982, § 14-101) 
Sec. 86-182. - Riding on sidewalk. 
    No person shall use any sidewalk in the business districts of the city for riding thereon with bicycles. On those sidewalks or paths of the city where riding bicycles thereon is permitted, the rider of the bicycle shall yield the right-of-way at all times to pedestrians on such sidewalks and paths. 
(Code 1957, § 5-10; Code 1982, § 14-104) 
State Law reference- Driving upon sidewalk, F.S. § 316.1995. 
Secs. 86-183-86-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PEDESTRIANS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Pedestrian control signals, F.S. § 316.0755; actions of pedestrians on approach of authorized emergency vehicle, § 316.126. 

Sec. 86-211. - Hitchhiking; selling to motorists. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to hitchhike or to solicit rides from the occupants of automobiles, trucks or other vehicles of conveyance within the corporate limits of the city, or to stand upon or loiter on any of the sidewalks, corners or streets within the corporate limits of the city for the purpose of hitchhiking or soliciting rides from the driver of any private vehicle, nor for the purpose of selling any merchandise or agricultural products, or in any manner to annoy motorists or others passing by, with signals, or by waving at, calling or otherwise attempting to obtain transportation gratuitously. 
(Code 1957, §§ 13-8, 18-9; Code 1982, § 14-116) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, F.S. § 316.008(1)(u); similar provisions, F.S. § 316.130. 
Secs. 86-212-86-220. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GOLF CARTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-05, § 1, adopted Dec. 2, 2008, set out provisions intended for use as art. VII, §§ 86-112-86-117. To preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as art. VII, §§ 86-221-86-226. 

Sec. 86-221. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions will apply, unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Golf cart means a vehicle with four wheels originally designed for use on a golf course, and powered by a battery or internal combustion motor. 
    Drivers license means a valid license to operate a motor vehicle issued within the United States. 
    Liability insurance means liability insurance not less than required by Florida law to operate a motor vehicle on public roads. 
(Ord. No. 2008-05, § 1, 12-2-2008) 
Sec. 86-222. - Restrictions. 
(a)  Golf carts shall not be operated on sidewalks or on public rights-of-way designated as bicycle trails. 
(b)  Golf carts shall not be operated on the following public roads: U.S. Highway 19, also known as North Jefferson Street and South Jefferson Street within the city limits; and U.S. Highway 90 (State Road 10), also known as East Washington Street and West Washington Street in the city limits; except for crossing at certain designated locations as indicated in this Article; or except when those streets are closed for authorized events. 
(c)  Golf carts not equipped with headlights, brake lights, lighted turn signals and windshields may be operated during daylight hours only. 
(d)  Golf carts may be operated only upon a city street that has been designated by the city for use by golf carts. The city shall post appropriate signage on the designated streets to indicate operation of golf carts is allowed on those streets. 
(Ord. No. 2008-05, § 1, 12-2-2008) 
Sec. 86-223. - Designated locations for crossing state highways. 
(a)  Golf carts shall be authorized to cross state highways only at locations to be determined by the Police Chief of the City of Monticello and approved by the Florida Department of Transportation. 
(b)  The city shall post appropriate signage on the city streets as an indication where crossing state highways is allowed. 
(Ord. No. 2008-05, § 1, 12-2-2008) 
Sec. 86-224. - Equipment and standards for operation. 
    In addition to the requirements of F.S. § 316.212, which are applicable to the operation of golf carts on roads and streets within the city, the following restrictions shall apply: 
(1)  All golf carts operated within the city shall meet the minimum equipment standards established by Florida State Statutes and have no increased power, wheel base or tire modifications from a standard manufactured gas or electric golf cart. Speed-modified golf carts or "hybrid" golf carts are not authorized for use on the city streets. 
(2)  All golf carts permitted under this section to travel on designated public streets and roads within the city shall have a maximum attainable speed of 20 miles per hour. 
(3)  All golf cart operators within the city must be a minimum of 16 years of age and hold a valid driver's license, which must be in the operator's possession at all times while operating a golf cart on public roads. 
(4)  The number of occupants in any golf cart being operated within the city shall be restricted to the number of seats on the golf cart. No occupants of a golf cart shall stand at any time while the golf cart is in motion. 
(5)  All golf carts must be equipped with efficient brakes, reliable steering, safe tires, a rearview mirror, and red reflectorized warning devices in both the front and rear at all times while operated on designated roads and streets within the city. 
(6)  Golf carts must be operated in accordance with all traffic regulations, and their operation must not obstruct nor interfere with normal traffic flow. 
(Ord. No. 2008-05, § 1, 12-2-2008) 
Sec. 86-225. - Registration, insurance, and hold harmless agreement required. 
(a)  Golf carts that may operate on designated city roads and streets shall be registered with the city on an annual basis. The registration process shall include payment of an annual registration fee, which shall be set by Resolution of the city council. Decals reflecting a valid registration must be visibly affixed to each registered golf cart in accordance with requirements of the city. 
(b)  Before golf carts may be operated on designated city roads and streets, the owners thereof must purchase and maintain liability insurance, insuring against personal injury and damage to property of any nature relative to the operations of golf carts on designated city roads and streets. Proof of insurance must be presented during the process of registering the golf cart with the city, and documentation of insurance must be available on the golf cart at all times. 
(c)  Hold harmless agreement required. Any person operating a golf cart on any designated street does so at his/her own risk and must operate such vehicle with due regard for the safety and convenience of other motor vehicles, bicyclists and pedestrians. The city in designating certain city streets for the operation of golf carts extends such operating privileges on the express condition that the operators of any golf carts under this article undertakes such operation at their own risk and assume sole liability for operating the vehicle on the designated streets and by such operation agree to defend, release, indemnify and hold harmless the city, its officials and employees for and regarding any and all claims, demands, or damages of any nature whatsoever arising from such operation by any person. Furthermore, in consideration of and in return for the privilege of operating said golf cart on the designated streets, the owner shall sign a defense release, indemnity and hold harmless agreement as part of the registration. 
(Ord. No. 2008-05, § 1, 12-2-2008) 
Sec. 86-226. - Penalties. 
(a)  Violations of this section shall be enforced pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 316.212(8) and F.S. ch. 318, as applicable. 
(b)  In addition to the foregoing, violations of traffic infractions shall also be punishable by any other method as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2008-05, § 1, 12-2-2008) 
Chapter 90 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, adopted June 3, 2010, amended Art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. I, §§ 90-1-90-8, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1957; Ord. of 4-5-1977; Code 1982; Ord. of 8-6-1985; Ord. No. 89-07, 10-3-1989. 

Sec. 90-1. - Making sewer or water connection across property of another. 
    This chapter shall not be construed to require or entitle any person to cross the private property of another to make any sewer or water connection. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-2. - Unlawful connection to city line. 
    No person shall be allowed to connect into any water line or sewer line owned by the city without the written consent of the city, and then the connection with such line shall be made only under the direction and supervision of the city manager. Any property owner or plumber who shall make any connection without such consent of the city manager shall upon conviction be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-4 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-3. - Connecting old plumbing to city line. 
    Whenever it is desirable to connect old plumbing with the city sewer main and/or water line, the owner or plumber contemplating doing such work shall notify the city manager, who will inspect said old plumbing and notify the owner or plumber what alterations will be necessary to place said old plumbing in an acceptable condition for such connection. Any owner or plumber who shall make any connection without the approval of the city manager shall, upon conviction, be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-4 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-4. - Maintenance of pipes and connections. 
    The owner of the property shall be responsible for maintaining and keeping clean the water and sewer pipes leading to and connection from the plumbing system to the city distribution lines and main sewers. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-5. - Free service prohibited. 
    No water or sewage disposal service shall be furnished or rendered free of charge to any person, firm or corporation whatsoever; and the representative and each and every agency, department or instrumentality which uses either or both such services shall pay therefore at the rates fixed by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-6. - Installation and ownership of water and sewer lines outside city limits. 
(a)  In the event of an application for the city to provide water and/or sewer utility services to a location outside the city limits, a condition prerequisite to the provision of such utility service shall be that the owner of the property to be served by the utility: 
(1)  Properly execute at the time of application for utility service, a nonrevocable, recordable petition to annex into the city at such time as the property becomes eligible for annexation under the laws of Florida. 
(2)  If the property is contiguous to city limits, pay to the city at the time of such application the prevailing fees charged by the city relating to annexation which shall include, without limitation, fees to amend the future land use and zoning maps. The city clerk shall have the petition to annex duly recorded in the public records of Jefferson County, Florida, whereupon the petition shall constitute public notice of the matters reflected therein. Property owners of a location outside the city limits receiving city utility services as of the date of this ordinance are exempt from these provisions. 
(3)  Applicants seeking such service shall pay the cost of construction from the existing lines, either inside or outside the city limits, to the premises to be served in those areas where no line or lines exists. When construction is necessary, the same shall not be commenced until a written agreement is approved by the city council addressing ownership and maintenance of the system, payment of construction costs, tap fees, systems charges and provisions for approval of construction plans by the city. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply in the case of 100 percent grant-funded water and sewer main extension projects, provided that the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The property for which city water and/or sewer service is sought must be immediately adjacent to the right of way where the water and/or sewer main extensions are constructed; and 
(2)  Not later than forty-five (45) days after substantial completion of the grant-funded water and/ or sewer main extension project, the owner of the property must apply for immediate connection to such water and/or sewer main extension. "Substantial completion" of the project shall be as defined in the construction contract documents for the project. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 6-3-2010; Ord. No. 2015-01, § 1, 3-3-2015) 
State Law reference- Water connections outside city, F.S. § 180.19. 
Sec. 90-7. - Rate contracts. 
    The city council shall, notwithstanding the enumerated rates for water and sewage established in this chapter, be authorized to contract with owners of multiple family, multiple occupant or multiple consumer apartments, houses or trailer parks for a specified monthly sum as and for water and/or sewage usage; provided, however, that such contract utility billing and monthly rate shall be based upon the current rates then in existence for all users, giving proper credit for the collection of same to the owner or owners. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-8. - No temporary suspension of water or sewer billing. 
    The city will not suspend water or sewer billing to accommodate temporarily absent owners or seasonal residents. 
(Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Secs. 90-9-90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SEWERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-04, § 5, adopted June 3, 2010, provides that this ordinance shall become effective the beginning of August, 2010. 
State Law reference- Pollution of waters, F.S. ch. 387; sewage disposal, F.S. § 403.085 et seq.; municipal public works, F.S. ch. 180. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-31. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, for each such offense, be subject to punishment in accordance with section 1-4 of this Code. Any failure or refusal by an owner to connect to the city sewer system after notification so to do, as provided in this article, or any failure or refusal to pay the charges or rates provided in this article shall be construed to be a violation of this article and a misdemeanor of the second degree. 
(Code 1982, § 21-13; Ord. of 8-6-1985, § 18; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-32. - Connection with public sewer required. 
    The owner of each lot or parcel of land within the city, upon which lot or parcel of land any building, or trailer used as a dwelling is now situated or shall hereafter be situated, for either residential, commercial or industrial use, shall connect or cause such building or buildings or trailer or trailers to be connected with the public sewer facilities of the municipal sewer system of the city and use such facilities within three months following notification so to do by the city manager. All such connections shall be made in accordance with rules and regulations which shall be adopted from time to time by the city council of said city, which rules and regulations shall provide for a charge for making any such connections in such reasonable amount as such council may fix and determine. No connection or connections shall be required where said sewer system or line is more than 200 feet from such lot or parcel of land. 
(Code 1982, § 21-2; Ord. of 8-6-1985, § 2; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-33. - Right of city to make connection. 
(a)  If any such owner of any lot or parcel of land within the city shall fail and refuse to connect with and use the facilities of the sewer system of the city after notification by the city manager, as provided herein, then the city manager shall be authorized to make such connections, entering on or upon any such lot or parcel of land for the purpose of making such connection. The city shall thereupon be entitled to recover the cost of making such connection, together with reasonable penalties and interest and attorney's fees, by suit in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  In addition and as an alternative means of collecting such costs of making such connections, the city shall have a lien on such lot or parcel of land for such cost, which lien shall be of equal dignity with the lien of state and county and city taxes. Such lien may be foreclosed by the city in the same manner provided by the laws of the state for the foreclosure of mortgages upon real estate. 
(Code 1982, § 21-4; Ord. of 8-6-1985, § 4; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-34. - Sewage disposal facilities required. 
    No person, group of persons, firm or corporation shall build or remodel or cause to be built or remodeled any structure used for human habitation or occupancy within the city which is within 200 feet of a public sanitary sewer line, unless it is provided with water-carried sewerage facilities. 
(Code 1982, § 21-6; Ord. of 8-6-1985, § 7; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-35. - Sanitary facilities required. 
    Every residence and building in which human beings reside, are employed or congregate shall be required to have a sanitary method of disposing of human excrement, namely either a sanitary water closet that is connected with the city sewer system, or an approved type of septic tank. A septic tank will be used only if the property is more than 200 feet from the sewer line. 
(Code 1982, § 21-8; Ord. of 8-6-1985, § 9; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-36. - Unlawful disposal of sewage. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, persons, firm or corporation owning or leasing any premises in the city to permit the disposal of any human excrement on any property, leased or rented by any such person, firm or corporation or the agency of any such person, firm or corporation, except in a sanitary water closet where sewage lines are available as defined above. 
(Code 1982, § 21-9; Ord. of 8-6-1985, § 10; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-37. - Septic tanks. 
    No septic tank other than those approved by the state health department shall be constructed within the corporate limits of the city. No septic tank shall be constructed within 200 feet of the sewer line. 
(Code 1982, § 21-10; Ord. of 8-6-1985, § 11; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-38. - Failure to maintain plumbing system. 
(a)  Failure to keep the sewer pipe, i.e., the pipe leading from the plumbing system to the city main, clean and maintained in a proper manner will give the city the right to cut off the water connection, which shall not be reconnected until the sewer pipe is cleaned and maintained properly. 
(b)  Clean out valves are required at the connection to the city main and located every 75 feet along the private property sewer line for all newly-constructed sewer connections. Clean out valves are required to be set within a covered utility box. 
(c)  In those instances where the owner has his/her own private water supply, the city shall have the right to cut off such water supply to the plumbing system, and the owner shall have no right to reconnect his/her own private water supply until the sewer pipe leading from the plumbing system to the city main has been maintained and cleaned and in proper condition. Any violation of this provision by reconnecting his/her private water supply or the connection from the city water line, until such sewer pipes are cleaned and maintained properly, shall be considered a violation of this article and subject to the penalties provided in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 21-12; Ord. of 8-6-1985, § 15; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-39. - Tapping permit and fee. 
(a)  Inside city limits. 
(1)  The city will furnish sewer taps of all sizes up to and including four-inch sewer taps upon application and payment of the costs and fees, which fees shall be promulgated by the city council from time to time and posted at city hall. The fees and costs shall be payable in advance for each new tap, and such fees and costs shall apply to each separate tap for single- and multiple-family dwellings or businesses. The city reserves the right, under certain circumstances, to negotiate prior to issuance of a permit on multiple-family residences for greater or lesser amounts, depending on the extent of the city's labor and services required. 
(2)  In addition to the above, there shall be a charge not to exceed the actual cost of removing and replacing concrete or asphalt driveways, sidewalks or pathways. Such costs shall be paid in full before sewer service shall commence. 
(3)  Should any existing tap be inoperable through nonuse, damage or failure to be serviceable, the city shall make such repairs, renovations or rehabilitation as shall be necessary prior to the connection of the system; and the property owner shall pay the actual cost thereof prior to the issuance of a building or occupancy permit. 
(b)  Outside the city limits. 
(1)  There shall be a tap-in fee charged for installation of city sewer service provided to residents outside the existing city limits, which fee shall be promulgated by the city council from time to time and posted at city hall. Additionally, the property owner shall be required to pay the actual costs of all required materials. The fee shall be payable in advance and at the time of the application for such tap. Sewer service outside the city shall not be provided except under the provisions of article I, section 90-6 and section 90-41. 
(2)  In addition to the above, the property owner shall be responsible for removing and replacing concrete or asphalt driveways, sidewalks or pathways. 
(Code 1982, § 21-14; Ord. No. 88-06, 10-4-1988) 
Sec. 90-40. - Deposit required for sewer service. 
    For all applications for sewer service, the applicant will be required to post with the city a deposit as outlined in article III, section 90-129. 
(Ord. No. 2008-02, § 1, 2-5-2008; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-41. - Providing sewer-only service outside the city. 
    Effective June 1, 2010, no premises located outside the city limits shall be connected to the city sewer system without corresponding city water service except under the following conditions: 
(a)  The property owner complies with provisions of article I, section 90-6. 
(b)  An appropriate water meter or sewer mater is installed on the property, and the account owner executes an agreement consenting to provisions in subsection 90-61(i) below. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Secs. 90-42-90-60. - Reserved.

Sec. 90-61. - Schedule of sewer rates and charges. 
(a)  Accounts with water meter:

Outside City Limits Base Rate: $18.36 $22.95 Additional Charge: $4.62 per 100 cu. ft. or fraction thereof $5.77 per 100 cu. ft. or fraction thereof  
  
(c)  Unmetered residential sewer-Only accounts (only allowable to service locations with no readable water or sewer meter in existence as of May 31, 2010). Unmetered residential service locations which are served by city sewer service shall be assessed sewer discharge of 425 cubic feet per month. 
(d)  Unmetered nursing homes sewer-Only accounts (only allowable to service locations with no readable water or sewer meter in existence as of May 31, 2010). Unmetered nursing home sewer service locations which are served by city sewer service shall be assessed sewer discharge of 110 cubic feet times bed capacity per month. 
(e)  Unmetered church/school sewer-Only accounts (only allowable to service locations with no readable water or sewer meter in existence as of May 31, 2010). Unmetered church/school facility locations which are served by city sewer service shall be assessed sewer discharge of 30 cubic feet times student capacity unit per month. 
(f)  Unmetered unclassified sewer-Only accounts. Other unmetered sewer service locations will be assessed by estimation of usage by the city manager. 
(g)  Contracts with large users. The city reserves the right to enter into contracts with large users of water and/or sewer service for the purpose of setting and determining a monthly charge or rate for the use of such services, which monthly rate or charge may be computed upon a different basis than set forth in the immediately proceeding paragraphs. Such contracts shall be entered into by means of a resolution duly adopted by the city council. 
(h)  Septic treatment. The city will only accept waste delivered to the city wastewater treatment facility via tank truck from a Jefferson County residential or commercial address. Payment of septic disposal fees must be made in advance at the city hall utility office, and proof of payment must be presented to the treatment facility attendant at the time of disposal. 
    Treatment facility attendants reserve the right to establish operational rules for hours available for disposal, types of waste accepted, and screening methods required. The city reserves the right to refuse acceptance of waste when not in the best interest of the city. 
    The charge for disposal of septic tank waste into the city's wastewater treatment facility will be set by resolution of the council. 
(i)  Collection of charges where owner has private water supply. Where sewage disposal fees are not paid in accordance with provisions outlined above, in those instances where the owner has his/her own private water supply, the city shall have a right to cut off such water supply to the plumbing system, and the owner shall have no right to connect his/her own private water supply until the sewage disposal fees shall have been paid in full. Any violation of this provision by reconnecting his/her private water supply, until such sewage disposal fees are paid in full, shall be considered a violation of this article and subject to the penalties provided in this article. 
(j)  Miscellaneous charges and billing provisions. Sewer accounts are subject to provisions for billing; payment of charges; discontinuance of service for nonpayment or returned checks found in article III, section 90-163. 
(k)  Provision for limited sewer billing adjustment for extenuating circumstances. 
(1)  In the event of a significant spike in a customer's water usage which causes an increase in the corresponding sewer charge for a billing cycle, an account holder may apply for a sewer bill adjustment, which adjustment would be in the form of a recalculation of the account's sewer charge to equal the sewer charge based on an average of water used for the previous six billing cycles. Sewer billing adjustments are subject to the following provisions: 
(a)  Only sewer charges applied and billed in accordance with the sewer rates in effect since the July, 2010 billing are eligible for adjustment. 
(b)  Water usage for the billing cycle applicable to adjustment must equal two times the average of the customer's previous six months' water usage. For accounts with fewer than six months of billing history, the water usage for the adjustment cycle applied for must equal two times the average of the available months' measured usage. 
(c)  An account which, during any of the prior six billing cycles, had a usage measurement of zero due to blocked access to a meter or due to meter tampering is not eligible for a sewer charge adjustment based on a sudden spike in measured water usage. 
(d)  A request for sewer charge adjustment must be approved by the city manager. 
(e)  No more than one sewer billing adjustment per account is allowed within a consecutive 12-month period. 
(2)  The city manager reserves the right to authorize a one-time annual adjustment per account to a single cycle's sewage charge based on verified information that a portion or all of measured water usage during that cycle was not disposed of in the sewer system. Additional adjustments to the same account during a 12-month period may not be authorized except by vote of the city council. 
(3)  In the event of an extreme weather situation or other unforeseen occurrence which may cause an anticipated increase in outdoor water use, the city council may elect, by resolution or by ordinance, to adjust the percentage of water usage allocated to a corresponding sewer charge. 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 6-3-2010; Ord. No. 2010-08, § 1, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2013-06, § 1, 8-6-2013; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 2018-02, § 1, 1-9-2018) 
Sec. 90-62. - Sewer system development charge. 
(a)  There is hereby established a sewer system development charge, the proceeds of which shall be deposited in a sewer system charge fund for the purpose of long and short-range planning, construction of additions to system plants and lines, payment of principal and interest when due on bonds sold to finance such improvements, and the construction of extensions and expansion of the sewer system of the city. The revenues from such sewer system development charges shall be used exclusively for the city sewer system and shall be used to defray the capital costs of construction and other directly related expenses and costs required solely due to growth and expansion of the system. The sewer system charge fund shall be maintained in a separate account and in a manner to ensure that the funds therein are used only for the lawful purposes described. No later than at the time a building permit is issued, the person requesting such building permit shall pay to the city, in addition to the tapping charge heretofore provided for, the sewer system development charge as set forth in full in this section; except that any person exempt from obtaining a building permit shall pay such sewer system development charge at the time the tap fee is paid. 
(b)  The sewer system development charge shall be based upon residential equivalents and set by resolution. 
(c)  The city council shall conduct a review of the sewer system development charge rate on a periodic basis, but at least once every five years. 
(Ord. No. 2006-13, § 1, 11-20-2006; Ord. No. 2010-04, § 2, 6-3-2010; Ord. No. 2013-10, § 1, 9-3-2013)

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-121. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit any member of the water department, fire department or other legally authorized person from repairing, servicing or otherwise handling any of the property of the water department whenever it may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-122. - Service authorized. 
    The water department is hereby authorized to supply water service to the citizens of the city and surrounding territory in accordance with the rates, rules and regulations provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-123. - Use of city property. 
    No material or apparatus of any nature whatsoever which is the property of the city shall be installed upon the premises of any person other than the premises of the city or the public areas thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-124. - Obstructing water department. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to, in any way, hinder or obstruct the water department in the performance of its duties. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-125. - Unauthorized use of water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain, draw or otherwise use water from any public or private hydrant, tap or spigot without first obtaining permission from a lawful source and paying the charges required for the use of the water; or to turn any service cock or cocks for the purpose of obtaining water without such authority or to in any manner obtain water from any water pipe connected to the municipal water system of the city without first complying with the rules and regulations of the water department. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-126. - Transporting water to other premises. 
    All water vended under the terms of the rules in this article shall be direct to the consumer only, and all applicants and customers of the water department by the acceptance of such water service agree that they will not under any circumstance or condition run any pipe or other conduit of any nature along, across, over or under any of the streets, roads, lanes or other highways or byways of the city for the purpose of transporting water on or onto any premises whatsoever other than the premises specifically and completely occupied by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-127. - Records; duties of city clerk. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep an accurate record of all persons using water supplied by the city and to apply minimum charges in accordance with the rates and charges established in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-128. - Responsibility for payment of charges. 
    It is specifically understood and agreed that the applicant shall be responsible for all charges incurred by the applicant for water, regardless of the location of the service, and that the charges may, at the option of the city, be transferred to any active account of the applicant and, upon being so transferred, shall become a part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-129. - Deposit required. 
(a)  Before rendering service of water or sewer, the city shall require a deposit as follows: 
(1)  Water and sewer. An initial deposit of $145.00. 
(2)  Water only. An initial deposit of $75.00 
(3)  Irrigation only. An initial deposit of $25.00. 
(4)  Sewer only. An initial deposit of $110.00. 
(5)  Unmetered non-residential sewer only accounts. An initial deposit of $225.00. 
    Deposits are not transferrable between persons without written permission of the deposit-holder. 
(b)  Refund; unclaimed deposits. The deposit shall be held by the city until final settlement of the consumer's account, including any outstanding garbage fees, and shall be applied to any unpaid balances for city services. Any unused balance of the deposit shall be refunded to the customer at his or her last known address contained in the city's records. Undeliverable refund deposits or deposit refunds returned by the post office shall be assessed an administrative fee of $7.00 per month. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010; Ord. No. 2014-03, § 1, 9-2-2014) 
Sec. 90-130. - Connections generally. 
    Where the same shall be available, the owner of every lot or parcel of land within the city limits may connect, or cause the plumbing of any building or buildings thereon to be connected, with the available municipal waterworks system of the city, and use the facilities of such system. All such connections shall be made in accordance with the rules and regulations which shall be adopted from time to time by the city council, which rules and regulations shall provide for a charge for making any such connections in such reasonable amount as the council may fix and determine. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-131. - Tapping permit and fee. 
(a)  The city will furnish taps of all sizes up to and including three-quarter-inch and the water mains upon application and granting of fee, together with the payment of the tap fee as per the schedule of fees promulgated by the city council from time to time. There shall be required a separate permit and tap fee for each residence or business, and all multiple taps or buildings connected in a line shall be only with the permission of the city council. In addition to the tap fee as above stated, there shall also be a charge not to exceed the actual cost of removing and replacing concrete or asphalt driveways, sidewalks or pathways. Such fees shall be paid in full before water service shall commence. 
(b)  All property owners connecting to the city water service will be required to have a cut-off valve located on the property owner's side of the meter. Properties not equipped with such cut-off valves will be charged a service fee for temporary turn-off for repairs or emergencies as outlined in subsection 90-162(g)(4). 
(c)  Connections outside city limits. 
(1)  Water service outside the city shall not be provided except under the provisions of article I, section 90-6. 
(2)  There shall be a tap-in fee charged for the installation of city water service provided to residents outside the existing city limits of the city, which fee shall be promulgated by the city council from time to time and posted at city hall. Additionally, residents outside the city limits shall be charged for the cost of the meter and meter box and any other additional required material. 
(3)  Such tap-in fee shall be payable in advance and at the time of applying to the clerk and city council for such service. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-132. - Meters-Requirements; exceptions. 
(a)  Payment of costs. The water department shall, without cost, furnish and install meters of up to and including five-eighths by three-quarter inch on services within the city limits, but when a larger meter is required it must be paid for by the applicant or owner of the property served. 
(b)  Separate meter required for each owner, tenant and occupant. Effective June 1, 2010, no newly constructed premises or no existing premises intended to be subdivided into separate ownership or tenant units will be served through one meter, but each separate unit must be served through an individual meter and individual account for each and every owner, tenant or occupant. 
(c)  Exceptions; premises where single meter permitted. Premises where either furnished or unfurnished rooms are rented or leased may be supplied through one meter as may also hotels and boardinghouses and multi-building businesses where all such buildings are served under the direct control and use of the applicant. 
(d)  Waivers. The city manager may grant waivers for requirement of separate meters only after written petition by the property owner or owners affirming that re-plumbing of such premises is either impossible due to existing configuration of walls, buildings or plumbing facilities, or inaccessible service lines. Such waiver may only be issued upon written executed agreement, suitable for recording in the public records, indicating the property owner accepting ownership of the service line and agreeing to act as the single responsible party for the billing of the water usage and accompanying billing of sewer discharge. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-133. - Refusal of service. 
    The city reserves the right to refuse water service to any applicant or to discontinue service to any applicant on whose premises a violation of the rules in this article is found to exist. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-134. - Resale of water. 
    The city will not furnish water to any applicant for resale to others except where such resale is made after the water is removed from any piping or conduit connected to or under pressure from the water mains of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Secs. 90-135-90-160. - Reserved.

Such contracts shall be entered into by means of resolution duly adopted by the city council and with consultation by the Suwannee River Water Management District.

(2)  $10.00 for transfer of utility account owner to a new location.

(4)  $10.00 for temporary turn-off and reconnect due to a repair or emergency at the request of the customer. 
(5)  $25.00 for illegal water turn-on, and a charge for parts and labor will be made for damage recovery to any components of the meter, meter box or city plumbing. 
(6)  $25.00 for dishonored checks or automatic electronic debit entries amounting to less than $100.00, and $35.00 for returned checks amounting to more than $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010; Ord. No. 2014-03, §§ 2-4, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 2018-01, § 1, 1-9-2018) 
Sec. 90-163. - Billing; payment of charges; discontinuance of service for nonpayment or dishonored check. 
    Bills for water and/or sewer service shall be payable on the first day of each month; and if such monthly bill remains unpaid after the tenth day of such month, a standard late penalty of ten percent shall be imposed and added to said bill. If the tenth day of the month falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or holiday, the late penalty will be applied after the next full business day. The city is not responsible for postal service delivery; therefore, late fees will not be waived for non-delivery of utility bills. Past due amounts not paid before the next billing will be included in the following month's billing, and standard late penalties, when applicable, will be applied to both current and past-due amounts. On the 20th day of the month, customers who have outstanding balances from combined current and prior billing exceeding $25.00 will have their water service discontinued without further notice. 
    Accounts paid by dishonored checks returned to the city by a financial institution will be charged in accordance with subsection 90-162(g)(6). Returned checks will render the account delinquent and subject to immediate disconnection. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-164. - Reconnection of service to delinquent user. 
    Should any water or sewer customer be disconnected and his/her water service terminated, the city shall not reconnect or restore the furnishing of water services to the delinquent user until such time as all delinquent accounts have been paid in full at the city hall, together with a reconnect fee of $20.00. 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 6-3-2010) 
Sec. 90-165. - Water system development charge. 
(a)  There is hereby established a water systems charge fund for the purpose of long- and short-range planning, construction of additions to system plants and lines, payment of principal and interest when due on bonds sold to finance such improvements, and the making of extensions and expansion of the water systems of the city. The revenues received from such water systems charges shall be used exclusively for the city water system and shall be used to defray the capital costs of construction and other directly-related expenses and costs required solely due to growth and expansion of the system. Such funds shall be maintained in a separate account and in a manner to ensure that the funds are used only for the lawful purposes described. No later than at the time a building permit is issued, the person requesting such building permit shall pay to the city, in addition to the tapping charge heretofore provided for, the water system charge as set forth in full in this section; except that any person exempt from obtaining a building permit shall pay such water system charge at the time the tap fee is paid. 
(b)  The water impact fees charged pursuant to subsection (a), hereof, shall not apply to a second connection to the potable water distribution system when the second connection is solely for irrigation purposes. However, such installation shall be required to pay the water tap charge set forth in section 90-131. 
(c)  The water system development charge shall be based upon residential equivalents and set by resolution. 
(d)  The city council shall conduct a review of the water systems charge rate on a periodic basis, but at least once every five years. 
(Ord. No. 2006-03, 5-2-2006; Ord. No. 2010-05, § 2, 6-3-2010; Ord. No. 2010-09, §§ 1, 2, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2013-11, § 1, 9-3-2013)
